Title: Dalit man detained for not wearing mask dies in police custody in Andhra Pradesh
body: Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy has initiated a probe into the incident. A Dalit man died in police custody on Tuesday late night in Prakasam district after he was detained by the police allegedly for not wearing a face mask while riding on a motorcycle. The deceased Yericharla Kiran was undergoing treatment for a head injury in Guntur. However, he succumbed to his injuries. On July 18, Kiran was detained by the police for not wearing a mask and helmet in a COVID-19 hotspot of Chirala town in Prakasam district. According to police, Kiran and his friend Shini Abraham were moving on a motorcycle without masks and a constable Rami Reddy at Kothapeta check-post reprimanded them. Police allegedly found that the duo were in an inebriated condition. Police in a press note said that the duo created a ruckus and allegedly beat up the constable following which Sub-Inspector (SI) Vijay Kumar took them into custody. Police claim that Kiran jumped out of the moving police vehicle while being taken to the II Town police station, resulting in a head injury. The family members of the deceased allege that the police hit him on his head causing the fatal injury. Police said that Kiran was first shifted to the Chirala Government hospital and later to a private hospital in Guntur for better treatment. The incident has caused a furore in the state over repeated police violence against Dalits in the past two days. TDP general secretary Nara Lokesh, slamming the YSRCP government said, ├в┬А┬ЬDon├в┬А┬Щt Dalits have a right to live under Jagan├в┬А┬Щs regime?├в┬А┬Э Pointing out the cases of Varaprasad and Kiran, he said, ├в┬А┬ЬTo gain the appreciation of the ruling party leaders, police had tortured Varaprasad and now a Dalit youth Kiran Kumar in Prakasam district died due to police assault. Is there law and order in this state? The police who ought to protect the citizens have turned into lackeys of the ruling party and are attacking the Dalits like goondas.├в┬А┬Э Varaprasad, a Dalit man was tonsured and humiliated by the SI in Seethanagaram police in East Godavari district, allegedly at the behest of the local YSRCP leaders, over a feud involving a sand lorry. Meanwhile, on Wednesday, tension prevailed in Thomaspeta area of Chirala following Kiran├в┬А┬Щs death. Police deployed additional forces to prevent any untoward incident. Probe Initiated Kiran├в┬А┬Щs father Mohan filed a complaint against SI Vijay Kumar following which he was booked under IPC Section 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means). Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy initiated an inquiry into the incident and announced an ex gratia of Rs 10 lakh to the victim├в┬А┬Щs family. The inquiry would be led by Additional Superintendent of Police Gangadhar. Prakasam District Superintendent of Police Siddharth Kaushal handed over the case to Darsi Deputy Superintendent of Police for an impartial probe.  ┬й2021 the news minute

Title: Dalit Couple in Madhya Pradesh Assaulted by Cops, Cosume Pesticide
body: Poverty Did Not Push the Parents of These Dalit Children to Consume Pesticide. Police Brutality Did By Arr├й Bench Jul. 16, 2020 Just as the country was recovering from the news of the gruesome custodial deaths of Jayaraj and Bennicks in Tamil Nadu, another case of police high-handedness has come into the spotlight тАФ this time from Madhya PradeshтАЩs Guna. A Dalit couple was reportedly left with no choice but to consume pesticide, in a bid to commit suicide, after the police allegedly approached their land on Tuesday and began destroying their crops, reports said. ALERT: GRAPHIC CONTENTIn MP's Guna, a Dalit farmer couple consumed pesticide in front of his children, police officials after Guna authorities started destroying their crops with a JCB to evict them from a govt-owned land. My report for @TheQuint https://t.co/jA76YX9Vru тАФ Asmita Nandy (@NandyAsmita) July 15, 2020  The administration claimed that the 5.5 acres of land, on which the couple had been farming, belonged to the government and labelled Ram Kumar Ahirwar and Savitri Devi as illegal encroachers. The Dalit couple, meanwhile, say they had been farming there for years. When they saw the police bulldozing their crops, they drank the pesticide, because they had a debt of тВ╣3 lakh, and saw no other way out. тАЬWe donтАЩt know whose land it is. WeтАЩve been farming on it for a long time. When our standing crop was destroyed, we didnтАЩt have any option but to kill ourselves,тАЭ Savitri Devi was quoted as saying. Following this act, they were beaten by officers, even as they were being dragged to an ambulance. A disturbing clip showing the assault was shared widely on social media. This is inhuman! How can people in uniform behave like this??!!!!!! https://t.co/EM7QRoxcbX тАФ Kritika Kamra (@Kritika_Kamra) July 15, 2020  Another image of the Dalit coupleтАЩs children holding on to their parentsтАЩ unconscious bodies broke hearts on Twitter. When the kids tried to help their parents, they were verbally abused and pushed aside by the police, NDTV reported. A child holding onto his father who was brutally thrashed by Madhya Pradesh police in tiger ScindiaтАЩs Guna district and who ended up drinking pesticide as a result. If this image doesnтАЩt break your heart and make you angry then you donтАЩt have a heart. Horrific. pic.twitter.com/IxrCPRd7ie тАФ Rohini Singh (@rohini_sgh) July 15, 2020  MPPolice top leadership shd introspect how these men &women in uniform are any different from lawless mobsters. Suspensions and transfers alone bring no justice to the poor victims. Time for ruthless action against brutality and the courage to usher in systemic accountability. pic.twitter.com/qfgK83svW0 тАФ Indian Police Foundation (@IPF_ORG) July 16, 2020  The husband and wife are now stable and recuperating in a hospital. However, a number of cases have been filed against them, even as GunaтАЩs district collector gave the police officers a clean chit. тАЬHad the team (the police) not acted, the couple could have died and more cases could have taken place,тАЭ he said, to much outrage online. Guna collector gave a clean chit to police тАУ Our team had to act only after the couple consumed pesticide and had to be rushed to hospital, Had the team not acted, the couple could have died and more such cases could have taken place. @ndtv @ndtvindia#Guna @GargiRawat pic.twitter.com/8v0R1d0H2T тАФ Anurag Dwary (@Anurag_Dwary) July 15, 2020  Congress leader Rahul Gandhi shared the video on Twitter and wrote, тАЬOur fight is against this mentality and injustice.тАЭ рд╣рдорд╛рд░реА рд▓рдбрд╝рд╛рдИ рдЗрд╕реА рд╕реЛрдЪ рдФрд░ рдЕрдиреНрдпрд╛рдп рдХреЗ рдЦрд╝рд┐рд▓рд╛рдлрд╝ рд╣реИред pic.twitter.com/egGjgY5Awm тАФ Rahul Gandhi (@RahulGandhi) July 16, 2020  Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has now ordered an inquiry and removed the district collector, S Vishwanathan, and superintendent of police Tarun Nayak. Some on social media called for the chief ministerтАЩs resignation as well. The outrage was triggered when the Dalit couple attempted suicide after the officials thrashed them when they protested against their removal from the government land at #Jaganpur village near #Guna. #MadhyaPradesh | @Rahul_Noronhahttps://t.co/zlPAny6N1t тАФ IndiaToday (@IndiaToday) July 16, 2020  As the story continues to pick up steam, hopefully those actually responsible for grabbing the land, and the officers responsible for the merciless beating, will be taken to task. Arr├й Bench The Arr├й bench delivers stories that mattress. It hasn't achieved much sofar. But it's getting bedder.  Did you like it? Tell us what you think so we can give you more content you like : There are a slew of Instagram accounts run by media professionals dedicated to irritants and inside jokes of their job and industry. Lately, the conversation has slowly moved from the likes of тАЬThis client said this silly thingтАЭ to тАЬMy agency promotes mental health as long as it involves a yoga class, not reasonable work hours or manageable workloads. Haha. Fun.тАЭ This shift from LOLs and low-key whining to simmering aggression about toxic work culture during the pandemic is an eye-opener. WeтАЩve all heard of Javed Khan, the rickshaw driver who sold his wifeтАЩs jewellery to convert his vehicle into a mobile ambulance. Though heartening, these tales of sacrifices make me gloomy. Each one of these positive stories come with the unsaid failure by the state or those in a better position to help. As the second wave continues to batter India, тАЬwokeтАЭ media organisations and ad agencies are all about well-being and mental health. The problem arises when this performance of empathy does not extend to their employees. Stories of bosses expecting you to work beyond office hours and making one demand after another on WhatsApp groups are all too common. There are several reasons why this second wave of the coronavirus may prove to be more lethal than the first one. Most of it has to do with Indian behavioural impulses. Indians havenтАЩt been able to stand in a queue for the longest of time and it comes as no surprise that the pandemic-taught etiquette has worn off. In Dwarka, a man was so angry with his mother for getting into an argument with a neighbour that he slapped her in public. She died. Her death should be seen as the moment we call out the many abusive relationships the elderly live in, with death as their only escape. Your weekly dose of Arr├й Get the best from arre.co.in, straight to your inbox!  Follow Us: ┬й UDigital Content Private Limited, All Rights Reserved. Site by AREA 17 Technology Partner тАУ Monocept

Title: Old video from Rajasthan falsely shared as Dalit boy and girl stripped naked, thrashed in UP - Alt News
body: A video of a man and a woman paraded naked while a crowd records their video is circulating on social media. Hushyar Singh Meena (@HushyarMeenaIN) who identifies as ABVP Jaipur state secretary posted the video on June 26 and wrote, тАЬIt is being said that this incident took place in DeoriaтАЩs Sakrapar. Son and daughter of a Dalit were stripped naked and beaten. The youth were beaten only because they did not come on time to cut the harvest. The accused should be punished irrespective of where this video is from.тАЭ Alt News is refraining from embedding the video in this article due to its distressing nature. A screenshot has been attached below. [Translated from: рдпреЗ рджреЗрд╡рд░рд┐рдпрд╛ рдХреЗ рд╕рдХрд░рд╛рдкрд╛рд░ рдХрд┐ рдШрдЯрдирд╛ рдмрддрд╛рдИ рд╣реИ. рджрд▓рд┐рдд рдХреЗ рд▓рдбрд╝рдХреЗ рдФрд░ рд▓рдбрд╝рдХреА рдХреЛ рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░ рдХрд░ рдорд╛рд░ рд░рд╣реЗ рд╣реИ. рдлрд╕рд▓ рдХрд╛рдЯрдиреЗ рдирд╣реА рдЖрдП рд╕рд┐рд░реНрдл рдЗрд╕рд▓рд┐рдП рдпреБрд╡рдХ рдФрд░ рдпреБрд╡рддреА рдХреЛ рдирд┐рд░реНрджрдпрддрд╛ рд╕реЗ рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╕реНрддреНрд░ рдХрд░ рдкрд┐рдЯрд╛рдИ рдХреА рдЧрдИ. рдпреЗ рд╡реАрдбрд┐рдпреЛ рдХрд╣реА рдХрд╛ рднреА рд╣реЛ рджреЛрд╖рд┐рдпреЛрдВ рдХреЗ рдЦрд┐рд▓рд╛рдл рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╡рд╛рд╣реА рд╣реЛрдиреА рдЪрд╛рд╣рд┐рдП.]  The clip is circulating on Facebook and Alt News has also received several fact-check requests.  This video dates back to April 2017. Alt News has already debunked it in the past. As reported by Hindustan Times, the incident took place in Shambhupura village in Banswara district of Rajasthan. After a Khap like diktat was issued, Kachru (20) and his cousin with whom he was allegedly in a relationship were thrashed and paraded naked in the village. Both the victims belonged to the Bhil tribal community of Rajasthan. тАЬThe police said that a case has been registered under relevant sections of the IPC and the Information Technology act against five individuals and around 10-12 unidentified persons,тАЭ added the report.  During a Mirror Now broadcast, SP Anand Kumar stated, тАЬA girl and a boy from the same family eloped a few days earlier. Since it was a family affair, they did not inform the police and began a search operation on their own. They were eventually found in Gujarat yesterday, and around 10-11 am they were brought back to the village. No one was informed and they were stripped and thrashed. No one was aware of the incident and the boy was returned to his family while the girl was married off immediately. A WhatsApp video and photos came to the fore, after which the SHO went to the village and spoke to the sarpanch. No one was willing to talk initially but after digging a little it was found that the incident indeed took place. The police traced the boy and has taken him in confidence. He was reluctant to give details at first but eventually filed an FIR. тАЭ Therefore, a video of a 2017 incident from Rajasthan was revived with the false claim that a girl and boy from a Dalit family were mercilessly thrashed. However, this was a case of honour-based violence as the couple, who were relatives, eloped together. Donate Now A video of a woman sporting a cropped and ripped denim jacket is making theтАж A set of three videos, in which a group of men assault a man withтАж A video of a band of children making music out of empty tin cans andтАж A video of two sadhus in a car apprehended by a mob has been sharedтАж A video of a crocodile carrying a dead woman in its mouth has been sharedтАж

Title: MP CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan orders removal of Guna Collector, SP after Dalit couple consumes poison
body: Bhopal: A Dalit couple allegedly consumed poison while they were being evicted from their homes. An inquiry was ordered into the incident after police officials were seen using force on the deceased couple. A probe was ordered into the case by Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh. According to a recent development, Chouhan also ordered the removal of Guna collector S Vishwanathan as well as Tarun Nayak, the SP of Guna district on Wednesday. The incident took place on Tuesday when an eviction drive was being carried on government land. The deceased man was identified as Rajkumar Ahirwar. Initially, the government had tweeted that the couple consumed poison after they were "instigated by some people". The 45-bigha government land in Jaganpur Chak was allotted to construct a college but the same land was encroached upon by Gappu Pardhi, a 'land mafia'. Gappu had allegedly rented the land to Rajkumar for farming. When the revenue officials went to the area for the encroachment, Rajkumar and his family raised an objection. In the video that went viral, the police could be seen thrashing the couple with lathis. Rajkumar and his wife were being kicked by a policewoman. A senior official quoted the CM and said, "My government will take strong action against mafia and criminals but force is not to be used against common people. " The incident came to light when a video of the cops using force on the family went viral on social media, The Times of India reported. In the video, the couple's children could be seen crying as they sat near the bodies of their parents. Home minister Narottam Mishra said that they have taken cognizance of the case. He said that a team comprising senior officials was sent to Guna to investigate the case.

Title: Drive to clear land: After Dalit couple suicide bid, Guna Collector, SP out
body: S Vishwanathan and SP Tarun Nayak were removed late on Wednesday night and a probe ordered after a Dalit farmer couple consumed pesticide to protest against an anti-encroachment drive, with police allegedly beating up a relative in response. A photograph of the children of Rajkumar Ahirwar and wife Savitri, who are stable, crying next to their unconscious mother on Tuesday, and a video showing police beating up AhirwarтАЩs younger brother had gone viral. Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan announced the action against the Collector and SP late on Wednesday night. Officials had arrived with a bulldozer at the 45-bigha Guna land reserved for a government post-graduate college, a major chunk of which has allegedly been encroached upon by Ahirwar. An attempt to clear it in November last year had been blocked by the family of Gappu Pardhi, who claims to own the land. Ahirwar told the officials that he had taken the land on lease and raised loan to cultivate it, and the family would have no option but to end their lives if their crop was destroyed. After the couple consumed pesticide, the police had booked them as well as others for trying to obstruct public officials on duty. Before he was removed, Collector Vishwanathan told The Indian Express that the police had to use force as AhirwarтАЩs relatives were not letting them take the couple to hospital. He also said the government had sanctioned Rs 12 crore for construction of the college, and any further delay could have resulted in it being shifted to another district. The Collector said the Ahirwars might have been instigated by someone to take the step, to stop the team from clearing the encroachment. Home Minister Narottam Mishra said senior officials from Bhopal will probe the incident and take action against whoever was responsible. The Congress said the video of police officers thrashing AhirwarтАЩs relatives and bundling them into a vehicle showed that it was тАЬjungle rajтАЭ in Madhya Pradesh. тАЬIf there was some dispute about the land, it could have been solved legallyтАж Will the government show similar alacrity in clearing encroachment on thousands of acres of government land by so-called jan sevaks (peopleтАЩs servants)?тАЭ asked former CM Kamal Nath. ЁЯУг The Indian Express is now on Telegram. Click here to join our channel (@indianexpress) and stay updated with the latest headlines For all the latest India News, download Indian Express App.  Milind Ghatwai ... read more

Title: ├втВм╦ЬTumi Key?├втВмтДв The Stunned Dalit Girl says, ├втВм╦ЬI am Asiad Gold Medalist, an Arjuna Awardee.├втВмтДв ├В┬╗ Northeast Today
body: Jyotirmoy Prodhani On 13 July one Ranger and his beat officer from the Belacoba Forest Range in Jalpaiguri, North Bengal, raided the house of Swapna Barman at Gomostopara village near Jalpaiguri for alleged possession of timber without papers. The Range Officer went there with a full platoon, at least three SUVs and half a dozen armed guards in combat fatigue with the preparedness of dealing with any dreaded forest mafia. They got down from the vehicles, rushed to Swapna Barman and triumphantly pointed guns at her as if they had just caught hold of a prized timber Don. During heavy monsoon, the river Teesta overflows and that is also the time when tree logs come floating which some of the local enthusiasts try to pull ashore. These logs are then sold at a much cheaper price in the local markets. This has been a phenomenon every monsoon. In fact, the floating logs have become so predictable that it has become a sort of monsoon festival to collect logs from the Teesta. As the water recedes, it even becomes easier to drag the logs from the dry river banks. The forest department, on the other hand, is not known to have chased the logs though most of the logs are well sectioned tree stems apparently get drifted from the piles of felled logs from inside the forests. One reason of this inertia on the part of the department being that too much of monitoring on the drifted logs might well open up a cupboard for more skeletons to tumble down as most of these logs are unaccounted timbers ostensibly felled as part of the irregular chopping of forest trees. But this time for the lone pair of such logs there was extraordinary eagerness and hyperactive drives on the part of the forest department. Therefore, this time they had raided the house of Swapna Barman, a daughter of a rickshaw puller, a native Rajbanshi Schedule Caste girl, whose family, till the other day, just could manage two square meals a day. But the situation slightly changed when Swapna Barman became the only Indian so far to have won the gold medal in the 2018 Asian Games in the event called heptathlon, an athletic event which, like many of them, most of her own villagers never heard of till she won the medal. Earlier, she had also won a gold medal in the Asian Athletic Championship in 2017 and got a silver medal in the SAF Games in 2016. Being the champion of one of the toughest athletic events she soon became well-known all over the country. For her extraordinary sporting achievements, she was also conferred with the coveted Arjuna Award. In the same Asiad Games, Assamese girl, Hima Das too won the gold medal in the 400 metres mixed and womenтАЩs relay. Young Hima Das deservedly became a celebrity in Assam. She has also been offered the job of DSP by the state government. In stark contrast to such glorious journey, Swapna Barman received a lukewarm welcome in Kolkata airport, the capital of her home state, moderate cash rewards from the state, and that is about it, where it all ended. Swapna belongs to the Koch Rajbanshi community, an indigenous repressed community recognized as Scheduled Caste in the state of West Bengal. But in the caste sensitive Bengal society, they have always been considered as pariahs, the low castes; the mainstream castes of Bengal even twisted a term to describe them as the Bah├йs, a Rajbanshi colloquial term of respect turned into a derogatory word by the mainstream Bengal to stigmatize the entire community. In a well-known Bengali novel (TeestaParerBrittanta) the community is symbolically represented by a loin clad semi civilized character, Bagharu. The popular novel has forever immortalized the image of naked Bagharu as the quintessential identity of a Rajbanshi in Bengal. Swapna Barman belongs to this community who are, for the mainstream Bengal, a ridiculous Bah├й, a Bagharu, a semi civilized, quasi savage entity. Swapna Barman, as was revealed later, was constantly cajoled for about three days by an incumbent to buy a pair of floating logs from him. The desperate seller finally could dump two timber logs in the front yard of her thatched house. Like most of the people in the village, she finally agreed to purchase the log. But before even a lone plank of the wood could be used, the very next morning the forest department, on a тАШtip-offтАЩ appeared in lightning speed and she was caught тАШred-handedтАЩ dealing with illegal timber. This apparently highly тАШlaudableтАЩ forest activism generated a variety of responses. Predictably, the mainstream Bengal media turned the forest officers as the ultimate protagonists, the champions of forest protection. The arrival of the forest team was well organised and well equipped. Right on their landing, about half a dozen guards aimed their guns at Swapna and another half a dozen opened their mobiles and cameras to shoot videos of Swapna being тАШcaughtтАЩ, a scoop for the media that the forest officials brought to cover the event. Swapna was seen pleading the lady beat officer not to take videos of her because that would ruin her career which, she said, тАШI had painstakingly built for the last nine years. I toiled with my sweat and blood to reach here. Please donтАЩt destroy me.тАЩ Then came running her brother to stand in front and said it was he and not his sister who had got those logs. The half a dozen gunmen then turned their guns to the young boy, put him in a corner and forced him to squat on the ground, the boy then ended up looking helplessly at the barrels pointed at him. When Swapna ran to her brother to protect him from assault, then Panchali Ray, the тАШupright and highly activeтАЩ Beat officer dragged out Swapna to face the guns again. When Swapna was still pleading to listen to her, and let her explain, the тАШuprightтАЩ beat officer asked that famous question, тАШTumi Key?тАЩ (Who are you?) Surely before she came to the house of Swapna Barman, the most famous address of Gomostopara, she did not come as an ignorant as to where they were heading to for the catch. She could not be as dumb. In fact, she did not ask the question to get an answer; rather she had asked the question to give an answer. With that question she had instantly turned Swapna into a persona non-grata; with that question, the Beat officer had actually shown the wretched daughter of a rickshaw puller, a Rajbanshi bahe, a low caste pariah, as one with despicable social credibility, what she actually was. Swapna was reminded by that question that she was an expendable non-entity, no matter what might have been her achievements for the country. The Range Officer showed his officious authority by issuing her challans to show the papers of those logs within 30 days sharp and heroically zoomed off after giving precious bytes to the media which they had brought along to the spot. However, when they had departed with the satisfaction of having effectively ruined Swapna as the videos got uploaded within seconds to circulate SwapnaтАЩs ignominious fall, the same video also reached others- her community members, for whom Swapna was one of the very few reasons to be proud of. The incident turned to be a catalyst for one of the biggest mobilisations of the Koch Rajbanshi Kamatapuri community for a social cause in North Bengal. The incident even created a furore in Assam. The news story that followed in the mainstream media of Bengal screamed with the headline, Illegal Timber found at SwapnaтАЩs House. Curiously a moral brigade appeared who got тАШdevastatedтАЩ at such reprehensible criminal act of Swapna Barman. Some even demanded setting up of a bigger commission to investigate SwapnaтАЩs connections with the illegal timber traders. In short, they demanded enquiries into the links of Swapna in plundering the forest of Bengal. The District President of the Sports Association, Mihir Bandopadhyay was quick to project Swapna as a criminal, тАШNo matter how big a player she is, there must be exemplary actions against herтАЩ. One Purajit Bakshi Gupta of the District Sports Association seemed to have got equally devasted at SwapnaтАЩs crime, тАШAs a sportsman, I am aghast and ashamed.тАЩ(in UttarbangaSambad, 14 July 2020) The same newspaper wrote with enthusiasm, тАШSwapna broke down in front of the officers and finally gave in to admit her crime.тАЩ To the local Koch Rajbanshis the incident had given them a sense of d├йj├а vu, for this has been too familiar a pattern through which the Rajbanshis have been routinely criminalized by the mainstream narrative of Bengal. The virtual spaces on the mobiles crowded with uproar as the Koch Rajbanshi youths set the social media platforms ablaze. The video of humiliated Swapna got viral. The political parties, TMC and BJP found themselves in a Catch 22 imbroglio, the 45% voter share of the Rajbanshis in North Bengal is too pricey to be given away on a platter to the opponents. The forthright and straight-to-your- face community leader, the firebrand Bongshi Badan Barman, the Chairman of Rajbanshi Unnayan Parishad, called up the Chief Minister, Mamata Banerjee, and warned that the situation would go out of control if those officers were not taken to task for having plotted against the biggest Rajabanshi sporting icon and the CM must ensure removal of all the false charges against her. Almost soon after, Mamata Banerjee came on camera to castigate the two forest officials, ordered their transfers and declared Swapna as innocent. But curiously, her own Forest Minister had earlier showered praise on the two forest officers for having nabbed one involved in illegal timber trading. However, after her announcement, Babul Supriyo, Union Minister of State for Environment and Forest, was enraged at the CM for having encouraged the тАШplunderer of the precious forestтАЩ and for having discredited two of the most тАШpious forest officers of the countryтАЩ- Sanjay Dutta and Panchali Ray. When Babul SupriyoтАЩs video statement had gone viral, the BJP sensed trouble at the growing anger of the Rajbanshis against the party, so soon Babul Supriyo amended his statements. It turned into a macabre political comedy of sort. This incident, however, is not an isolated one, it is part of a pattern through which the Rajbanshis in Bengal have been criminalized, racially discriminated against and socially castigated. This incident was preceded by another event where a gang of extortionists had locked up a house in Coochbehar and driven out the owner of the house who was a Rajbanshi school teacher. The extortionists had demanded Rs. 10,00, 000/- (rupees ten lakhs) as a тАШdonationтАЩ to be paid by the teacher in order to get back his own house. All the three extortionists happened to be Hindu Bengalis who had to be arrested following extraordinary public protests and pressure. There are reasons to believe that SwapnaтАЩs incident might as well be a calculated act to remind the Rajbanshis that the land, the erstwhile Kamrup Kamata, in which they have been living for centuries, no longer belonged to them. The transfer orders of the two high caste Bengali officials immediately followed by a volley of racist and despicable misogynist slurs in the social media against the community and Swapna Barman. The racist and misogynist slurs were so vile and abusive that several Koch Rajbanshi women organisations from Jalpaiguri had to approach the cyber cells to formally lodge complaints. The Swapna Barman episode was followed by another tragic incident in North Dinajpur, where, on 19 July, a 16 years old Rajbanshi school student was allegedly raped and brutally murdered. As the protest erupted the Bengal media reported the incident as the protest of irate people at the тАШdeath of a girlтАЩ. This time the suspected perpetrator appeared to be a Muslim following the recovery of his mobile and his bicycle at the spot. Officially the incident was quickly termed as suicide. Since the perpetrator appeared to be a Muslim, the BJP got overactive and turned into the biggest supporter of the Rajbanshis. The body of the rape and murder suspect was found a couple of days later. This time the TMC government turned too swift to arrest the father, the uncle and younger brother of the 16 years old rape and murder victim. Earlier, on 12 July, the Rajbanshi MLA from Hemtabad constituency in North Dinajpur, Debendranath Ray, was found hanging in the verandah of a shop in the market. Nobody believes the official version that he went to the market and committed suicide. This is symptomatic of Kafkaesque existential experience of the Koch Rajbanshis in Bengal who have been brutally subjected to repressions and been reduced not just into peripheral disjuncts but into effective non-entities. The author teaches at North-Eastern Hill University, (NEHU) Shillong. ItтАЩs a powerful story. In the world of prejudices against Dalits and the tribal, how easy it becomes to malign the rarest of the jewels that the community may produce once in their life time. This is not how the affluent criminals are dealt with.

Title: Telangana: Dalit girl found dead, family alleges rape and murder
body: Kothagudem: On July 8, a 17-year old Dalit girl, who was allegedly raped and murdered according to the family, was found dead on the railway tracks connecting to the Garimellapadu village. According to the sources, the girlтАЩs dead body was found naked and bruised. A resident of Ganga Bishen Basti of Kothagudem, the girl recently completed her Intermediate. Locals claim that the girlтАЩs ex-boyfriend might have sexually assaulted and killed her. Another local report on social media claims that the parents found her talking to a guy in the neighborhood, which escalated into a brawl between both the families involved. The girl is known to be missing after the episode. The girlтАЩs parents filed a missing report with the local police station, but to no avail. According to the preliminary investigation by the Government Railway Police, the minor died in a train accident. Police believe that the girl could have been hit by a train scheduled between 2 AM and 3 AM. The post-mortem confirmed this. However, due to suspicions, the police said that the suicide angle cannot be ruled out. Meanwhile, many took to social media to express outrage about this incident. A petition to deliver justice to the girlтАЩs family is being shared all over the internet. тАЬThe police have actually been denying solid evidence solely because of this boyтАЩs political background,тАЭ the petition states. The petition also points out that the case is not being prioritized because of the girlтАЩs Dalit identity. The police, however, denied these claims made on social media. Title: Caste Dismissed: Dalit Schooling in Colonial India with Dr Sumeet Mhaskar
body: In this episode with Sumeet Mhaskar: We discuss the caste system, India, untouchability and the efforts in 1800s Maharashtra, India to educate the Dalit caste.   Show Notes: 0:52: What is a Dalit? 2:58: Pre-colonial educational system 4:16: Educational initiatives started by Indians 5:15: First School Open to Dalits in 1848 8:00: Violence against educating Dalits 11:00: Jyothirao PhuleтАЩs Vision for educating India 16:00: Anticaste activism of Jyothirao Phule 23:00: Challenging the ritual position of Brahmins 26:00: Did anti-caste activists compromise with colonialism? 29:00: British Prioritizing and Promoting Brahmins 31:00: The Concept of untouchability and what education did for that 34:00: Dr. Ambedkar and his vision for caste-based liberation 36:00: Negotiation vs collaboration with the colonial state 41:00: SumeetтАЩs Project on Bombay textile mills Prof. Dr. Sumeet Mhaskar is as an Associate Professor and Associate Dean (Student Affairs) at Jindal School of Government and Public Policy, O. P. Jindal Global University in NCR of Delhi, India. He is also a Research Partner with the Max Planck Institute for the Study of Religious and Ethnic Diversity in Goettingen, Germany. You can find him on twitter For your security, we need to re-authenticate you. Click the link we sent to , or click here to log in. No posts

Title: MP Police brutality on Dalit family: BJP Govt faces flak, removes Collector, SP - Maktoob
body: Everything is Written Here A Dalit couple who allegedly attempted suicide in front of their children and police officers on seeing a JCB machine crush their standing crop was brutally assaulted by the policemen in Madhya PradeshтАЩs Jagatpur Chak area of Guna district on Tuesday. Ramkumar Ahirwar and his wife Savitri resisted the government teamтАЩs bid to evict the coupleтАЩs family from a piece of тАЬgovernment-owned landтАЭ and went on to consume pesticides. Following this, the policmen assaulted the farmer couple and forcibly dragged them into an ambulance. Ram KumarтАЩs mother and brother, who tried to save them, too were brutally assaulted by the cops. The Dalit coupleтАЩs children tried to rush to save their parents and the crying children were verbally abused and pushed away by the police. The duo were immediately shifted to the nearest government hospital and the latter is said to be critical. Former state Chief Minister Kamal Nath took a dig at BJP Government alleging it of running a тАЬjungle rajтАЭ in the state. рдпреЗ рд╢рд┐рд╡рд░рд╛рдЬ рд╕рд░рдХрд╛рд░ рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢ рдХреЛ рдХрд╣рд╛рдБ рд▓реЗ рдЬрд╛ рд░рд╣реА рд╣реИ ? рдпреЗ рдХреИрд╕рд╛ рдЬрдВрдЧрд▓ рд░рд╛рдЬ рд╣реИ ?рдЧреБрдирд╛ рдореЗрдВ рдХреИрдВрдЯ рдерд╛рдирд╛ рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░ рдореЗрдВ рдПрдХ рджрд▓рд┐рдд рдХрд┐рд╕рд╛рди рджрдВрдкрддреНрддрд┐ рдкрд░ рдмрдбрд╝реА рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛ рдореЗрдВ рдкреБрд▓рд┐рд╕рдХрд░реНрдорд┐рдпреЛрдВ рджреНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛ рдЗрд╕ рддрд░рд╣ рдмрд░реНрдмрд░рддрд╛ рдкреВрд░реНрдг рд▓рд╛рдареАрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдЬред1/3 pic.twitter.com/lRgOFaWHPp If our crop is destroyed, we donтАЩt have any other option but to kill ourselves: Family The Madhya Pradesh government had allotted the 20 bighas public land for construction of a Model Science College two years back, but the Dalit family has been practicing cultivation on it for a long time. тАЬWe donтАЩt know whose land it is, weтАЩve been practicing cultivation on it for a long time. We had taken possession of this land after paying Rs 3 lakh to Gabbu Pardi, a real estate businessman. If our standing crop is destroyed, we donтАЩt have any other option but to die by suicide. My husband have a debt burden of Rs 3 lakh. Who will pay it, the government or anybody else?тАЭ Ram KumarтАЩs wife Savitri Bai asked. FIR against family Meanwhile, instead of acting against the police brutality, the police have registered FIRs against the couple and other locals present at the spot. Among other charges, Section 353 of the IPC (Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty, Section 309 of the IPC (Attempt to suicide) have been added to the FIR. Videos showed policemen thrashing the coupleтАЩs mother and children. Video- police beating, shame on you @ChouhanShivraj @JM_Scindiapic.twitter.com/0P7TxkYKkJ Speaking to The Quint, state IG Gwalior Range Raja Babu Singh defended the police action and said the video has been clipped and is being shared as police weilding lathis on locals but the police was actually trying to shoo away the people who were resisting the cops from taking the unconscious farmer couple to the hospital Govt removes Collector, SP from posts After facing massive criticism from opposition, the Guna SP and the Collector, who had ordered the eviction drive and supported police action, were removed from their posts on Wednesday. тАЬWeтАЩve probed the entire episode and checked the entire footage of the incident. Our team had to act only after the couple consumed pesticide and had to be rushed to the hospital. Had the team not acted, the couple could have died and more such cases could have taken place. The action was also essential as some others present on the spot were hell-bent on making the incident even more serious, but our priority was to rush the couple to the hospital. The couple is now out of danger,тАЭ Guna district collector S Vishwanath earlier told media. Narottam Mishra, State Home Minister in a tweet, said a high-level inquiry has been ordered into the matter.

Title: Police charge at Dalit protestors in Janakpur - The Record
body: News 2 MIN READ Abha Lal, July 5, 2020, Kathmandu Share this article The stateтАЩs heavy-handed response to Dalit demands  The Dalit Struggle Committee of Dhanusa organized a protest on Thursday, July 2, in Janakpur to demand justice for Shambhu Sada and Raju Sada, two young Musahar men who died in police custody and a government quarantine facility, respectively, in the last month. Police fired tear gas and warning shots into the air, and charged the protestors with batons, seriously injuring Bijap Kumari Sada, Kalyan Kumar Sada, and Ramchandra Mahara--who are seeking treatment in hospitals in Janakpur and Dharan--and injuring at least a dozen others. One police officer is also reported to have been injured. Protests had been going on in Janakpur since mid-June, when Shambhu Sada, a 23-year-old truck driver from Sabaila Municipality was found hanging in the bathroom in police custody. Many, including SadaтАЩs mother, believe that the police murdered Sada, while others think that the police drove him to suicide, through physical and emotional torture. Anger grew when a couple of weeks later, 16-year-old Raju Sada died for want of treatment for diarrhea while waiting for his COVID-19 test report in a government quarantine facility--he later tested negative for the virus. While government probes were launched to investigate both incidents, protestors say that necessary action was not taken in response to either of the events. According to Pacchu Majhi, a member of the Dalit Struggle Committee, the protestorsтАЩ immediate demands include compensation for both of the deceased mensтАЩ families, and the suspension of police officers and medical supervisors held responsible for the deaths. According to journalist BP Sah, between 4,000 and 5,000 people, mostly from Dalit communities around Janakpur, had come to the town in tractors and gathered in Barabigha field for the protests. The protestors made their way from Ramananda Chowk to Piradi Road through to Madhes Bhawan, where Pacchu Majhi said that there was an altercation. тАЬWe had told the protestors to keep everything peaceful and not cause any trouble. The plan was to hold a minute of silence for Shambhu and Raju. One person threw a rock at the gate of the Chief MinisterтАЩs office, and thatтАЩs when the police became violent,тАЭ Majhi said. тАЬWe controlled the crowd and told the police officers that the remaining proceedings would be completely peaceful, but they started beating old people with sticks and firing shots in the air.тАЭ BP Sah told The Record that the police mostly beat the people who were at the tail end of the protesting crowd, who were mostly elderly people and women. Sah was detained for a couple of hours for allegedly тАЬinstigatingтАЭ the protests. Janakpur SP Ramesh Basnet refused to answer questions about why a journalist was detained, but said that the protestors had created chaos and that force was necessary. тАЬThere was stone-pelting outside the Madhesh Bhawan and a vehicleтАЩs window was also broken. ThatтАЩs why we began the lathi-charge,тАЭ Basnet said. Both Sah and Majhi believe that the police escalated the violence even after the stone pelting stopped. тАЬShambhuтАЩs mother made a narrow escape. She was directly in the line of fire outside Madhes Bhawan. The police were threatening people, telling them that they would go to their villages and shoot them,тАЭ Majhi said. Journalist Bhola Paswan, who has been following issues pertaining to Dalits closely for many years, told The Record that Dalit Struggle Committees across the country have been holding meetings about how to take the movement forward. тАЬThe anger from one incident has barely died down when another gruesome event happens. I think the protests are likely to continue to grow. I have been witnessing a lot of organizing happening,тАЭ Paswan said. :::::::: Abha Lal Abha Lal is a former Associate Editor and current contributor to The Record. Title: Dalit woman thrashed in Churu | Jaipur News - Times of India
Tamil Nadu: 7-year-old Dalit girl brutally raped and murdered by neighbour; people outraged - Tamil News - IndiaGlitz.com
body: You can update your channel preference from the Settings menu in the header menu. You can update your channel preference from the Settings menu in the header menu.  In yet another outrageous incident, a 7-year-old Dalit girl who went missing on June 30 was found dead yesterday evening in a forest area near her village with severe injuries on her face. She was allegedly raped by her neighbour before the murder. The incident has been reported from the Pudukkottai district of Tamil Nadu, where the girl had gone out to play at 4 pm on June 30. Her father filed a complaint with the police after they looked for her all over the area when she did not return home by 7 pm. The girl's body was found in a forest yesterday evening with grievous injuries on her face. It was found that she was raped before the murder, but the exact cause of death will be determined when the post-mortem report is out. An investigating official reportedly told TNM, "The girl was playing outside her home at 4pm. Her parents then found her missing and her father filed a complaint at the station at around 7pm. Efforts were then underway to find the girl. She has been beaten with sticks on the face and injuries are clearly visible. The post-mortem will reveal the actual cause of death." The accused, a 25-year-old neighbour of the girl, apparently took advantage of the fact that the girl was all alone out on the streets. "During inquiry he admitted that he had sexually assaulted and murdered the girl, Further investigation is underway and we will have more clarity once we get the post mortem report," a police official said, according to TNM's report.

Title: Mayawati demands high-level inquiry after villagers stop Dalit woman's cremation in Agra
body: Jump to navigation Speak Now Following an incident in the Achhnera area of Agra where a Dalit woman's body was removed from a burning pyre by upper-caste men, BSP chief Mayawati has demanded that the Modi government to order an inquiry into this incident and punish the culprits strictly so that such incidents are not repeated. Mayawati said that the Modi government should leave its casteist mentality aside and provide monetary assistance to the affected family. The incident took place in the Raibha village of Achhnera block in Agra where a woman's cremation was stopped by upper caste men on July 20, but the police did not take any action even after eight days of the incident. The woman had to be cremated outside the crematorium because of the protest by upper caste residents of the village. The local police did not take action against the culprits and kept trying to force a compromise. The police also made them perform the cremation outside the crematorium. After videos of this incident went viral, the SSP Bablu Kumar has taken cognizance of the incident, setting up a team led by the circle office Achhnera and asked to submit a report. 25 people have been booked under Section 151 of the CrPC. CO Achhnera VS Beer Kumar said the police had immediately reached the spot upon receiving the information but the affected family did not want any action to be taken against the culprits. Bhagwan Singh of Raibha said there are about 24 families of Dalits in Raibha and they want action to be taken against the culprits, they will not say anything. Congress city president Devendra Kumar Chillu told India Today that it is a shameful incident and there should be a high-level inquiry into the incident.He said the Modi government and its supporters are trying to suppress the Dalits and backward classes, but they will not succeed in this motive as the Congress will unite the Dalits, Muslims, and backwards against UP's Yogi government and Centre's Modi government, throwing them off. He demanded that the inquiry should be done by a retired judge. Minority leader and Bhartiya Muslim Vikas Parishad Chairman Sami Aghai said that the current government's slogan 'Sabka Sath Sabka Vikas' is the biggest farce as this government thinks of the 'Vikas' of the upper caste Hindus only, sowing seeds of hatred against the Muslims, Dalits and backwards in their minds. He added that the Achhnera incident is very shameful and strict action should be taken against the guilty. He said that a dead body has no caste and crematoriums and graveyards should not be allowed to be segregated according to castes. Title: After Cisco case, Dalit rights group collects testimonies on caste privilege in the US
Delhi's shame: The complete failure of rehabilitation of the manual scavengers ├В┬╖ Dalit Camera
body: In Shahdara, Seema has opened a small parlor in the Valmiki Basti. She says, тАЬI have seen the men of my neighbourhood die doing this. They have slowly vanished in the sewer one after the other. One goes and the other follows. She says I saw Ravi die in front of me.тАЭ Written by Pragya Akhilesh|Delhi|July 23, 2020 Firstly, we have to make sure that we organise our data and repeatedly follow up with people after the process of both rescue and rehabilitation. Individuals need to collect their very own data as the one provided by the government, the National Commission for Safai Karmacharis (NCSK) and the NGOs can be obsolete and incomplete. The informal settlements of Delhi which are not completely authorised rarely have sewer lines and establishment of a person engaged in this work is as difficult as gathering the information of an unauthorised area having a septic tank. It is also important to understand that it is difficult to collect substantial data of the people engaged in this work because no one wants to agree and say that they are forcing someone or that someone is willfully entering the septic tanks. The data, collected and then provided by the institutions for research work on rehabilitation also consists of many inconsistencies. In many cases, as the person has often migrated into the city from other states, the lack of contact information is persistent in nearly all sets of data. In particular cases, the name of the deceased is also wrong because the deceased was known with a secondary name. The Safai Karmachari Andolan of Bezwada Wilson has a far better grasp of this data which NGOs and institutions can request from the network in the case of rehabilitation of manual scavengers. Each year the government identifies more people as manual scavengers but fails to provide a viable rehabilitation model to the manual scavengers and the families of the deceased people because of these septic tanks. Together with a strict ban we also need integrated ways of rehabilitation for these people, not just singular promises of livelihood or distribution of loan pamphlets. Individuals, Institutions and both the central and state government have to change their approach when it comes to rebuilding the lives of the manual scavengers in India.тАЛтАЛ These are the real stories of people whose lives are forcefully tied to the work of manual scavenging directly and indirectly. These people face the reality of this trap every single day. They are in desperate need of different ways of rehabilitation. We have failed to emphasise the complete integration of various structures within and outside an individual. In this column, we have tried to sociologically understand the failure of rehabilitation and restoration from a few cases over the last 5 years through the Rehabilitation Research InitiativeтАЩs Archive: Delhi Chapter. In Pooth Kalan, near Rohini, AshokтАЩs body is being handed over to his family. His family members are shocked and confused. They say we donтАЩt have faith in God anymore. We donтАЩt know how we will eat now. In Ghitorni, DeepakтАЩs family is struggling to make ends meet. Both Deepak and his friend Balwinder died cleaning the septic tanks two years ago. His neighbour Mohan says, тАЬI have seen them going every day to Babus for compensation. I told them, you never get compensation, they make you feel that you died because you were a rat, you belonged in the tank. This is our work. You know, another man died the same day. I think his name was Svarn or something. You come to Delhi without family, here you are not scared. There is so much pressure to send money back. You do anything to survive.тАЭ Mohan is right, nearly half of the people who have lost their family members cleaning the sewers do not get compensation. If the compensation comes, it is never the full amount, that too, after running after people and Babus for days at a stretch. Mohan says while compensation is one problem, the other half of it is peopleтАЩs treatment towards us. He also says that people behave as if they are throwing the money at us. In the case of receiving compensation, the compensation only lasts for 6 months or a year. Here, other means of livelihood and rehabilitation become the main issues. In most cases, the person who has died was the only earning member of the family. In Shahdara, Seema has opened a small parlor in the Valmiki Basti. She says, тАЬI have seen the men of my neighbourhood die doing this. They have slowly vanished in the sewer one after the other. One goes and the other follows. She says I saw Ravi die in front of me.тАЭ After a long pause, she sings a song slowly. She is mourning within the scope of her song. She continues, тАЬI donтАЩt like waxing. I hate giving foot massages to women and I donтАЩt know how to cut. I will probably hire a girl for that but then how will I give the rent of the parlour, I donтАЩt know. I think if some of us women from Jhilmil did this together, I would have had more time to spend with my son.тАЭ In the case of SeemaтАЩs Parlour, an NGO approached Seema. It seems that before reaching her, they would have come to Shahdara to cover the death of Ravi who died of asphyxiation in the sewer, a few weeks ago. After 6 months Seema is seen struggling with this business as she needs to hire more employees specialised in services that are expected to be there in a Parlour like this. The cost of employing a person in this area can go up to 5000 rupees but in this case, her profitability is nearly 8000 per month. Every month Seema has to set aside 3000 rupees to pay the rent. The cost of keeping an employee is simply too high. This is making the business suffer as it is not able to provide all the required services. Here, when Seema opened her Parlour they only thought about the singular goal of opening a viable option of employability but did not take into account the problems that may arrive after rehabilitation. A linear method of rehabilitation does not assess the integrated connection between ever-changing goals post-rehabilitation of a case. Seema says when she narrated her problems, she was given a piece of National Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes Finance and Development Corporation (NSFDC) pamphlet. She found the schemes to be very complicated and could not follow it at all. She wanted someone to explain it to her so she kept calling this NGO for 4 months, but nobody replied. Ekta heads a Self Help Group of 50 women in Sonia Vihar. This Self Help Group comprises women whose families have been doing the work of scavenging for many years. Some of the women have been doing this work for more than two decades. Ekta says, тАЬnobody cares for us, we are left to fend for ourselves. So many people come to the Valmiki Basti for years promising us jobs. It hardly happens. I have four daughters to feed. Now I am learning to sew but I donтАЩt know where to sell them. NGOs do not understand that I cannot leave my daughters at home and go to work every day in remote areas of Delhi. I also cannot go from North Delhi to West Delhi every day as whatever I will earn will go on travel fare. These things restrict my choices.тАЭ In the case of Ekta, individuals have helped her in opening a Self Help Group. She hosts routinely meetings with the other women and till now has been able to gather more than 50 women to her Group. This approach of opening a Self Help Group is a very good socio-economic model for a woman in her position. The establishment of the Self-Help Groups (SHGs) has helped the rural communities in the absence of any other alternative credit facility, this, particularly in the last two decades, has mobilized more than 5.7 crore women in this country. The interaction with the rural communities facilitated by this model has helped in building non-farm livelihood opportunities leading to an unparalleled change in the rural-urban dynamic within Delhi. If SeemaтАЩs Parlour was opened in partnership with someone with similar interests, it would have probably been the solution to her problems. In SeemaтАЩs Parlour, the availability of other women would also have supported her in being able to spend more time with her son. Here, she and this group of women were also provided with a skill training session of sewing but these women did not know what to do after sewing these products. They lack the marketing skills which are required to sell these products. If these women do not sell these products they will begin to lose interest in this way of rehabilitation. This will also harm the health of the Self Help Group as more and more women will become disintegrated from this Group. This is why holding the hands of these women in the initial days of finding new ways of outlets to sell the products is very important. It is also important to teach these women these minimum tools of self-sustenance. Sanjay is a tailor in the Valmiki Basti in Farukh Nagar, Uttar Pradesh. He has trained Ekta and this Self Help Group in Sonia Vihar in operating sewing machines. He has taught them to make Salwars, Kurtas and Bags. Sanjay says, тАЬI can teach sewing to anyone in a monthтАЩs training yet when it comes to employing me they donтАЩt seem to care. I donтАЩt know why local boutiques donтАЩt keep me, something is always incomplete in my resume. This is what they say.тАЭ These are all examples of negligent ways of rehabilitating an individual. Within this, the emphasis on the structural integration of various systems is not valued. This is a тАШsingular/linearтАЩ rehabilitation approach. Institutions and individuals often plan to rehabilitate people with set goals. It has to be kept in mind that certain goals are only transitional goals, these goals are a part of a complex network of goals in a holistic rehabilitation. The mere objective method of rehabilitation for the achievement of a singular goal like opening up a business, enrolling a group of students in vocational training does not take into account the history, socio-economic and cultural background of a group or community. This application of knowledge breaks the linear method of rehabilitation and is called subjective rehabilitation. The third is the evaluative method which takes into account the physical and psycho-social health of an individual before opening up a business or an enrollment. It understands the limitations caused by the physical and mental health of a person and uses this knowledge to create an integrated way of rehabilitation. In the case of Sanjay, individuals who were trying to rehabilitate him by searching for a job based on his skills also have to apply their subjective knowledge of his socio-economic background during his rehabilitation. The lack of his employability can also be a case of caste discrimination. The integrated methodology of rehabilitation takes into account both the direct and indirect methods of rehabilitation. It focuses on the objective, subjective and evaluative systematic networked approach of rehabilitation. It acts as a sum total of micro-macro approaches that not only integrate symbolic interactions with social systems but also establish relationships between different network levels. In a specific case where a member has lost his individual and collective agency, it is important to understand that rehabilitation should be conceptualized in relational terms that are not just manufactured to produce the output of the study. Here, setting an interview in another individualтАЩs presence may help the discriminating employer to look at his combined skills. Asking persistent questions to this employer as to why SanjayтАЩs resume is not fit can put the employer on the spot so that he cannot get away with this behaviour. Meenakshi who is the resident of the same Basti in Farukh Nagar, says, тАЬfrom the last 5 years I have gone to numerous Skill Training programs sponsored by both the government and the NGOs. They teach us tally and Java. I donтАЩt follow it at all.тАЭ With Meenakshi, we have to expand into understanding why she is not able to follow the programs. Talking to her using different ethnomethodological techniques might help in understanding the outlying psycho-social problems that she may be going through. It can be the case that perhaps she is not able to share her problems with her family members. Here, sending her to these programs with a group of people who might not have the same socio-economic background, but people she relates to, like her friends from school might help her concentrate and enjoy these training sessions. Another aspect of it is that Meenakshi may be interested in other things than learning Tally or Java. The set syllabus of the vocational training has to be reset as per the individuals who are going to spend the time in these training sessions. MeenakshiтАЩs friend, Aarti lives in Loni, Banthla. She is an NGO Community Resource Person of this area. She says, тАЬI like to sing and act and then put it up on apps like Tik Tok and Likee. I want to be like Sapna Chaudhary. I donтАЩt know why they only want to teach sewing to us. I donтАЩt like sewing because I am not good at it.тАЭ She smiles and continues тАЬyou know women can do more than just cooking and sewing, they can become a star too.тАЭ AartiтАЩs brother Sourabh says, тАЬDidi my life is set, I am not in clouds like Aarti, I want to keep three buffaloes, open a small dairy business and from the profit of that one day I will go to Bombay and act in big films like Salman Khan.тАЭ AartiтАЩs sayings are quite accurate. She wants to break away from the confinements of gender roles. She is challenging individuals who only know the brick and mortar ways of rehabilitation to expand their understanding of digital media. Individuals need to learn ways of monetisation in digital media to help Aarti rehabilitate with her central skills. Sudha who lives in Tilla Village says, тАЬI lost my brother to Tuberculosis last year. He used to cough for many hours at a stretch. I have lost a child to TB too. I used to go there, clean the toilets of Bade Saab. They all told me not to go there anymore, but you tell me, what should I do? Now I collect waste from the houses and dump it in a nearby place. Didi, you think it is easy to pick up waste from these dust bins, you find dead pigeons, rats, meat carcasses in it. It is not different from the work I used to do.тАЭ Geeta Devi, SudhaтАЩs mother says, тАЬI go every day to clean toilets in a Bade SaabтАЩs house. She says the activists talk about rehabilitation from the work we do but still put us to do the same things. I am still cleaning the toilets. Yes, I am earning more now but I donтАЩt like this work. Why canтАЩt they employ us in one of the factories? The Yadavs in my colony still call me Kude waali/latrine safai karne waali.тАЭ Women from Geeta DeviтАЩs neighbourhood also spoke about the hasty generalization about putting all the castes under the same banner. They say some of the Yadavs in our colony also go inside septic tanks. Individuals who come to talk to us seem to lack the understanding of caste dynamics. Another woman says, тАЬThey think all of us have to be only Dalits. Yes, I am a Dalit woman but I am a Deha Dalit, a few migrated Shahanis also live in our Basti. People donтАЩt want to hear our stories, they just want to give us a speech on dignity.тАЭ Sudha and Geeta DeviтАЩs position is also a classic case of linear rehabilitation. They both need acute physical and psycho-social care. They have to be told that they can successfully do many things. Both of these women are being put up in a position where they are doing the same thing in a wealthier neighbourhood. This is taking a toll on their physical and mental health. Here, we see that people are often put in the same environment of cleaning toilets in colony homes. The displacement of an individual from one place to the other in similar roles do not solve the problems of dignity or sustenance. Individuals often get trapped in the cycle of self-doubt and lack of self-esteem because of repeated employment in similar areas. In other cases, too, opening a Sanitary Mart also poses problems of repeated employment in similar areas. Sudha says that the government keeps banning the supply of plastic bags so she has to use a Katta. The problem with it is that she has to use the same Katta to collect waste for months sometime. The non-availability of an alternative to a plastic bag makes the situation even worse. The government does not understand that merely counting the number of toilets and establishing it as a measure of success does not make IndiaтАЩs sanitation crisis any better. For every toilet that is constructed, there is also a case of a person being employed in the maintenance of these toilets. It is often the case that institutions lure the people engaged in cleaning septic tanks in their area in the pursuit of having to pay them less. Geeta Devi also says that the lack of water supply, disinfectants, toilet cleaners and preventive gears make the work as challenging as working in the dry latrine pits. Moreover, the availability of migrant labour, in this case, subsidises the workfare as now, Geeta Devi cannot demand a higher wage because more and more people are available to do the same job. Another thing is that individuals often do not understand the dynamics of different castes in India. A deep understanding of castes and intersectionality of caste with religion and gender is required before approaching people and trying to rehabilitate them. Individuals often hurt the sentiments of the very people they want to help. This is also a part of the subjective methodology of integrated rehabilitation. It is also true that we, as a society should be collectively ashamed about our lack of knowledge of the historical, socio-economic and cultural differences of communities. Individuals need to first read about the community they want to approach. In a few cases, individuals tell us that they are also often shamed more by other individuals in various institutions than the members of a particular community in itself. It is important to understand that in a particular case where you are not sure as to how to approach an individual, it is very important to ask questions rather than committing the fallacy of making hasty generalisations. Tulsi from Karawal Nagar says, тАЬgive me any job other than about toilets and latrines. I want to change my life. I wish my husband was here to see his children grow up. I can make you meet so many women in my colony who still do it every day.тАЭ Tulsi disappears for 10 mins. She then comes back with a following of 11 women. They narrate how they work in twos. In the evening they throw the collected dump of latrines together. They make sure nobody is seeing them. Priya says, тАЬyou know there is a ban on plastic polythenes, that is why.тАЭ All these women want to open a vegetable mart one day. One of them smiles and says тАЬI went to a big mall with my Baaiji one dayтАжyes! It is called Big Bazaar.тАЭ They all agree and say that they want to open a Big Bazaar in Karawal Nagar in the coming November of this year. All of them then write their names on a paper. Tulsi is seen struggling with depression after the loss of her husband. She says sometimes she does not want to wake up for days. She too needs immediate psycho-social care with routine therapy and counselling. Individuals also have to assess whether opening a Mart in this area will be economically viable. Firstly, opening a Self Help Group to make these women understand the basics of accountancy and maintaining the registers of the business will make them understand the realities of running operations of a small business. In Trilokpuri, Preeti says, тАЬI will marry very soon and then I will not be here.тАЭ Preeti runs a small Computer Centre, her students adore her. Neeraj, one of her students says, тАЬMaтАЩam, I think you will be here, I think Sir may allow you to do a job again. Preeti is now completely dependent on her husband. She did not realise that she was financially independent before marriage. The opening of a Computer Centre was a great possibility for her to break out of the patriarchal system. Individuals can counsel her but they have to respect her choice. In Mangolpuri, Sumit also runs a Computer Centre, he says, тАЬthese days everyone has a smartphone, I donтАЩt know why we are still teaching differences between hardware and software. I think if I teach my students video editing on the phone then it will help them in making their videos and finding jobs in these startups. If you have a stable job you donтАЩt drink that much.тАЭ SumitтАЩs father is a seasonal manual scavenger. He says, тАЬBaba keeps drinking because he does this work. Anyone who cleans latrines day and night will drink. One day I went to pick up Baba in the evening, I saw him drenched in latrine and waste. I used to think he collects waste and dumps it nearby.тАЭ Sumit is right, other members of the same family where one member does the work of manual scavenging also do not understand the extent and scope of this work. Sumit says that he used to not understand why his father would drink so much. We need to rehabilitate both SumitтАЩs father and Sumit. Now that Sumit completely understands the suffering of his father it is possible to expand the Computer Centre where SumitтАЩs father can also work and learn from his son. His father needs the love and affection of his son more than psycho-social care. Individuals and institutions often force manual scavengers to give up drinking without understanding the sequence of problems. Many people who clean the dry latrines and septic tanks have to resort to drinking and drug abuse because of a deeper problem that spirals in the breaking up of family ties. It can lead to the formation of deep emotional scars. Here, the evaluative methodology of rehabilitation can help the individuals to also understand that one cannot force a member to leave their families without making the members understand the consequences of their actions. Sumit also says that he is afraid of bringing people who want to help them to his house as individuals repeatedly advise his mother to leave his father because his father beats her mother. In cases of domestic abuse and violence which have spiralled from the drinking habit of a member of a family, individuals need to assess and inform women that they need to acquire and sort their finances before leaving the abuser. The complete evaluative procedure of not imposing your own morality and asking a woman to leave without her own choice has to be refrained from. Here, the woman can be counselled, given psycho-social care and an emergency number but leaving a person has to be her choice. Hence, there should be a deeper understanding of the integration between different levels of social systems before trying to rehabilitate someone. We, as a society have to also free ourselves from тАШour saviour complex.тАЩ Here, institutions need to have a diversified team of people from all socio-economic backgrounds. The presence of all kinds of representations should be one of the most important goals of institutions. Another important aspect is that the people of the team should be highly trained through orientations on different techniques of interaction that lead to a total or integrated rehabilitation. The author is a journalist and the founder of Rehabilitation Research Initiative. Currently, she is working as a consultant with the Safai Karmachari Andolan. From 2012 she has been the director of the repertory groups Lok Theatre, Bhim Dal and Ambedkar Manch in Delhi. Write to Pragya at [email protected] captures narratives, public meetings, songs, talks, discussion on dalits. It is largely run by students and their expenses are mostly met by themselves. Now heтАЩs a flame that is engulfing not only this country, but also the entire world. To my knowledge there has been no such event that reached the whole world, an event not only concerning Dalits, but any issue тАУ no incident attracted the attention of the whole world before. Read MoreContinue Mr. Tharoor, like most of the mainstream media in India, seems to be unaware of the arguments that are currently being made in opposition to the FYUP. The issue is no more confined to course structure or syllabi. Via The Hindu|Written byтАж Read MoreContinue Onam marks the age when slavery and the caste system were introduced into Kerala, an age which began with the killing of Maveli (Mahabali). Read MoreContinue When I ruminate these stories one things is loud and clear that caste and Christianity in India is actually old wine in a new jar. Both complement each other in overpowering the others quality. Christianity and caste in India have become conjoined siblings. Any move to separate these two are countered by hegemonic forces from both the sides. Read MoreContinue The HAF insists that scriptures that mandate caste are not widely regarded. This stance does not even enjoy consensus in their own community. Their former board, their spiritual leaders, and even Rajiv Malhotra, have all vehemently disagreed and asserted that bodies like the HAF do not have the spiritual authority to deem certain Brahminical texts more valid than others. Read MoreContinue Very holistic and cogently written write -up by Pragya Akhilesh. This is such a relief to read a fine piece, with the felicity of deep understanding of the issues and approaches to take rehabilitative measures for caste entrenched and perpetrated work of manual scavenging. This is a MUST read for all involved in social change and development work. Write more Pragya. Zindabad! Your email address will not be published. Title: TN Dalit family alleges minor was made to carry faeces for defecating in caste Hindu's land
body: The family has filed a complaint against the caste Hindu man for allegedly abusing and asking the teen to eat his excreta. In yet another instance of caste violence during the lockdown in Tamil Nadu, a caste Hindu man allegedly told a 14-year-old Dalit boy to eat his own faeces and forced him to carry the excreta for five metres since the boy defecated on a patta land owned by the former. The incident reportedly took place in Pennagaram of Dharmapuri district. The landowner, Rajasekhar, also allegedly abused the Class 10 boy with casteist slurs and assaulted him with a cane to force him to carry the excreta to his house. Rajesekhar belongs to the Iyer caste while the boy is from the Adi Dravidar caste, a Scheduled Caste group in Tamil Nadu. Following the incident, the boy's father has given a complaint to the police, based on which a case has been registered under the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes Prevention of Atrocities Act. According to the First Information Report accessed by TNM, the 14-year-old defecated in the open at 5 pm on July 15 as it was raining, on a land owned by Rajasekhar. On seeing the boy defecate on his land, Rajasekhar allegedly told him to eat the faeces and carry it in his hands. Rajasekhar also hit the boy with a cane to make him carry the excreta to his house, the FIR says. Fearing assault, the boy reportedly collected the faeces and walked for five metres till he reached home, the FIR adds. The humiliated boy is still unable to eat due to the incident, says his father. Talking to TNM, the father says, ├в┬А┬ЬIt was raining heavily on July 15 and my son got an umbrella from me and left home for defecating in the open. We have a toilet constructed by the Central government but we do not have water, so we defecate in the open. On that day also, my child was defecating on the land owned by Rajasekhar, when he passed by that way. On seeing the child, he immediately got down from the vehicle and started hitting my son with a cane for defecating in the open.├в┬А┬Э ├в┬А┬ЬRajasekhar told my son to eat the faeces since he had defecated on his land. He also uttered a casteist slur to my boy and told him to pick up the excreta with his hands,├в┬А┬Э alleges the father. Though a passerby tried to help the boy, Rajasekhar reportedly did not permit it. However, the passerby informed the father about what was going on. ├в┬А┬ЬBy then, my son just picked up the faeces and ran to our home. When I saw him, I was shocked to see him carrying the faeces. I asked him why he was carrying it and he told me that Rajasekhar had hit him and that he could not bear the pain,├в┬А┬Э the father says. ├в┬А┬ЬI immediately washed his hands. But still my child has not had food since he gets reminded of carrying the faeces in his hand,├в┬А┬Э adds the father. The Pennagaram Inspector said that the case is being handled by Pennagaram Deputy Superintendent of Police, Mehala. However, the DSP was unavailable for comment. The police have registered a case against Rajesekhar under Section 323 (Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt) of Indian Penal Code and Section 3 (1) (i) of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989.  ┬й2021 the news minute

Title: Tamil Nadu man booked for assaulting Dalit boy, forcing him to carry faeces
body: After Dalit residents of Kodarampatti village in Pennagaram filed a petition, police on Friday filed an FIR against the man, identified as K Rajasekar, under provisions of the SC/ST Atrocities Act Published: 17th July 2020 08:32 PM | Last Updated: 17th July 2020 08:32 PM | A+A A- For representational purposes DHARMAPURI: In a shocking incident, a 46-year-old caste Hindu man on Wednesday allegedly assaulted a 14-year-old Dalit boy, forcing the child to eat his own faeces and carry the excreta in his hands. After Dalit residents of Kodarampatti village in Pennagaram filed a petition, the Pennagaram police on Friday filed an FIR against the man, identified as K Rajasekar, under provisions of the SC/ST Atrocities Act for forcing a minor to undertake manual scavenging and for beating the child for trespassing into private land. According to the FIR, on Wednesday, the child was playing in the private land and defecated there. Rajasekar, the owner of the land, saw him and called out to him. When the 14-year-old approached him, the man allegedly started verbally abusing the child by his caste name. The FIR states that he pulled out a bamboo shoot, planted nearby, and thrashed the boy. It is alleged that Rajsekar then forced the child to eat the faeces. The 14-year-old, fearing further beatings, picked up the faeces and ran back to his home located some 15 metres away. The childтАЩs father told The New Indian Express that the boy is traumatised and has not spoken properly to even his family or friends since the incident. The boy had only defecated in the land because of the urgency of the situation. The child has also sustained physical injuries, he said. тАЬWe filed a complaint with Pennagaram police on Wednesday. They asked us to put the complaint in a petition box set up here because of the COVID-19 panic,тАЭ he said. Sub inspector M Mari looked into the complaint on Thursday and based on his investigation, an FIR was filed on Friday, said Periyar, the Pennagaram inspector. Periyar said Rajasekar has been booked under Section 323 of IPC for voluntarily causing hurt and under Section 3(j) of the SC/ST Act for forcing SC persons to do manual scavenging.
