Title: Op-ed: Persecution of the dalit community (down-trodden) in India - Global Village Space
body: The divisions in the Hindu society are obvious. A quarter of the Hindu population, the dalit, are not treated as equal citizens and denied access to even high-caste temples. A dalit leader Chandrashekar Azad addressed a rally to demand justice for Hathras (Uttar Pradesh) gang-rape victim. He is the `Bhim Army chiefтАЩ (a social body for protection of the dalit human rights). dalit community The speakers at the rally condemned governmentтАЩs failure to protect life and property of the dalit. He demanded licences and arms, subsidized at 50 percent to enable the dalit to protect themselves on their own. They pointed out that their demand was in sync with Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Rules 1995. They ventilated anger against police connivance with the high-caste community to hush up the molestation of dalit women by cremating her in mid night. They pointed out that it is customary in Hindu religion to cremate a dead body in the presence of near relatives. The believed family was cordoned off by a heavy contingent of policemen. They were not allowed to see journalists or opposition politicians. Even the opposition Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka were manhandled when they tried to reach the village Hathras. The opposition leaders were allowed to go there after nation-wide furor about high-handedness of the state and central governments. Read More: Babri Mosque case: Indian courts are no longer immune to Hindutva frenzy Besides concocting alibis for the absconding accused of heinous crimes against the dalit, the usual tactic is to play down the dalit protest. To do so they link dalit protests to Naxalite (Maoist) movement dubbing protesters as `traitorsтАЩ. The police rounded up even professors, poets and lawyers who wanted to participate in anniversary to celebrate Bhim Koregaon victory on December 31, 2019. A case in point is arrest of five prominent left-wing activists, dubbed `urban NaxalsтАЩ, and accused of funding the dalit protests. They were even accused of being linked to terrorists in illegally occupied Indian Jammu and Kashmir State. The arrestees are writer-poet P. Varavar Rao, lawyers Sudha Bhardwaj, Arun Fareira, Vernon Gonzaleves and Gotam Navalakha. The Koregaon Victory celebrations irked the high-caste Hindu as it aimed at commemorating the British victory (January 1, 1818) against Baji Rao Peshwa, a Maratha, by the dalit recruited in British army. The dalit had earlier asked the Peshwa to recruit them for fighting against the British army. But the Peshwa contemptuously rejected the request. Read More: Op-ed: Future of Muslims in India The Hindu caste-and culture code prevents high-caste Hindu to intermingle with the dalit community on equal terms. Dalit is supposed not to wear footwear in certain villages, ride a bicycle, or a horse, not to march his marriage procession in front of high-caste Hindu, and even dare worship in a high-caste temple. At a ceremony, five thousand dalit converted en masse to Budhism. A cursory look at oppression of the dalit during the past few years confirms that the dalit are treated as worse than animals in the Hindu society. The law enforcement agencies (police and judiciary) always support the high-caste culprits if a first information report is registered. The dalit were forbidden (October 5, 2003) by the upper caste Hindu to offer prayers at a Durga Puja congregation (тАЬPandalтАЭ) in Gopalichak locality of BiharтАЩs Bhojpur district (ARA, Bihar). An altercation between rival groups led to stampede. Instead of resolving the matter amicably, the police opened fire on dalit congregation, killing two dalit on the spot and injuring several others. A 28-year-old dalit youth was beaten to death by upper caste Hindus for daring to sit in verandah of Bhathiji temple (Gujarat Times News Network, Anand, Bhitasi village, August 10, 2003). According to news media), According to the police officials and social workers, `such incidents occur regularly, but only a handful are reported as members of the lower caste community still fear the wrath of the upper casteтАЩ. The dalit sanitary workers, frontline health staff, engaged against COVID 19 pandemic, are denied protective gear despite media outcry. Read More: India becomes тАШsuicide capitalтАЩ of the world, Modi amps military spending The official term for the dalit (including Hindu, Sikh, and Budhist) is Scheduled Castes. According to the 2011 Census, the dalit population in India is 200 million, excluding Muslim and Christian dalit. If the excluded are counted among the dalit, the actual figure would be about 300 million, a quarter of the countryтАЩs 1.2 billion population. IndiaтАЩs Scheduled Castes are distributed across 31 states and union territories. The states with the highest total numbers of SCs are Uttar Pradesh, with more than 40 million, and West Bengal with approximately 20 million. The less populous Punjab is the state with the highest proportion of SCs to its total population тАУ 31.9 per cent. dalit community Half of IndiaтАЩs Dalit population lives in four states (Times of India). Four states account for nearly half of the countryтАЩs dalit population, reveals the 2011 census. Uttar Pradesh stands first with 20.5% of the total scheduled caste (SC) population, followed by West Bengal with 10.7%, says the data released by the Union census directorate on Tuesday. Bihar with 8.2% and Tamil Nadu with 7.2 % come third and fourth. Dalits form around 16.6% of IndiaтАЩs population. Half of IndiaтАЩs dalit population lives in 4 states, among their population. Though UP has the largest chunk of the total SC population, Punjab has the largest share of dalits in its population at 31.9%. Himachal Pradesh and West Bengal follow Punjab with 25.2% and 23.5%. In Tamil Nadu, dalits account for about 18% of the population.There are around 9.79 crore women among the total SC population, and the sex ratio works out to 946 females per 1000 males. Nagaland, Lakshwadeep and Andaman and Nicobar islands have no scheduled castes. dalit community Read More: Pulwama investigations: Questions not answered by Indians ModiтАЩs India is trying to convert, hands in gloves with fascist Rashtriya Swayem Sevak Sangh (voluntary service association), into a Hindu rashtra (Hindu nation). But, the divisions in the Hindu society are obvious. A quarter of the Hindu population, the dalit, are not treated as equal citizens and denied access to even high-caste temples. Mr. Amjed Jaaved has been writing free-lance for over five decades. He has served federal and provincial governments of Pakistan for 39 years. His contributions stand published in the leading dailies and magazines at home and abroad (Nepal. Bangladesh, et. al.). He is author of eight e-books including The Myth of Accession. Title: Dalit woman raped And Murdered by 4 men - DeenPost
body: 19 year old was gang-raped in Uttar Pradesh, India. She died after two weeks of her being in a hospital and fighting for her life. The woman was tortured and raped by men in her village. She was brutally tortured and had several injuries on her body. A girl from Uttar Pradesh was raped and brutally tortured on September 14th. She was admitted to the hospital where she died after two weeks. She was a Dalit woman and four men raped her who were from the upper caste. She is from a village in a district called Hathras which is in Uttar Pradesh. She had several injuries and there were injuries in her spinal cord. Her tongue was chopped off by the four men. She was shifted to a hospital in Delhi. Also: Moinabad, Telangana girl raped and Murdered By Ruling Party Member Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh Akhilesh Yadav tweeted that the girl died today due to gang rape and torture, the government is not sensitive towards the crimes which are taking against women. Former Chief Minister Mayawati said that there should be strict action taken by the government. рд╢реБрдХреНрд░ рд╣реИ тАШрд╕рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕рддрджрд╛рд░реЛрдВтАЩ рдХрд╛ рдХрд┐ рдЙрдиреНрд╣реЛрдВрдиреЗ рдпреЗ рдирд╣реАрдВ рдХрд╣ рджрд┐рдпрд╛ рдЕрдВрдзреЗрд░реЛрдВ рдореЗрдВ рдордХрд╝реНрддреВрд▓ рдиреЗ рдЦрд╝реБрдж рдХреЛ тАШрд╣рд╡рд╛рд▓реЗ-рдП-рдЖрдЧтАЩ рдХрд░ рджрд┐рдпрд╛ pic.twitter.com/AhklEZvR08 The girlтАЩs father requested that the culprits must be hanged. When the girl went to the field she was grabbed and raped by the four men. The main culpritтАЩs name is Sandeep who was arrested. Later all three others were also arrested when the victim gave a statement. The girl was cremated by the police officers as there is a lockdown. The family was disturbed by the news about the death of their child. They wanted to cremate her as per the traditions but was not able to. рд╣реЗ рд░рд╛рдо ! pic.twitter.com/Zfu6lPpFGB The father of the girl said that he requested the police to allow them to cremate her in the morning but the police cremated her and the family was not able to see her. Also: UP: Homes On Street Painted Saffron In UP, Case Filed, BJP Minister. The girl has given a statement about the rape incident which took place after one week of her being admitted in the hospital. Priyanka Gandi from the congress party said that culprits are openly committing crimes and there is no protection. There are many cases of rape in India and it is reported that every 15 minutes a woman in India is raped as per 2018 data. Title: Man Who Married Dalit Woman Thrashed With Sticks In Gurgaon, Dies
body: he five accused knew that Akash had married the woman from the village, the police said. A 28-year-old man in Gurgaon died of injuries on Thursday after he was thrashed with sticks and lathis allegedly by a group of men on Sunday. The man's brother alleged that he had been receiving threats ever since he married a Dalit woman five months ago. On Sunday, the man and his wife had gone to meet the woman's parents when he was assaulted in the village of Badshahpur in Gurgaon. Five men have been arrested and cases of murder have been filed against them. The victim, Akash, was returning home in an autorickshaw when the three-wheeler hit which one of the accused, Ajay, who was walking on the road. "This led to an argument and a subsequent fight. Ajay called his friends and thrashed Akash and escaped. The accused were produced before court on Thursday and have been remanded in police custody," the officer said. The five accused knew that Akash had married the woman from the village, the police said.  His brother alleged in the First Information Report (FIR) that young men from the village had threatened him for marrying the woman from the Dalit woman. "Local boys upset with the inter-caste marriage had threatened my brother that they will not spare him if he enters the village," said Akash's brother, Rahul Singh. Akash is a member of a so-called upper caste community. Originally from Alwar in neighbouring Rajasthan, Akash and his wife lived in Gurgaon's Bhondsi. Title: Ayodhya: Dalit Gangrape Survivor Who Went To File Complaint, Reportedly Beaten Up By Constables
body: A gangrape survivor from Ayodhya has alleged that she was beaten up by two woman constables when she went to the police station to file a complaint of the assault. The survivor went to the police station on November 18 to record her statement. тАЬTwo women police constables pressured me to change my statement even though I was speaking the truth. They hit me. They kicked me and even used their belts to beat me. I was asked to take off my clothes, but I did not,тАЭ the Dalit woman who was gang-raped on November 16, was quoted as saying by The Week. Representattional Image The police have registered a report and arrested the two men named by the survivor. Based on her complaint, the two women constables accused of beating her up, have been suspended from duty and an inquiry is underway. "We have provided adequate security to the victim. The police will extend all possible help in the matter," Shailendra Kumar Singh, SP (Rural) said. File Photo Reports suggest the rape took place on November 16 during daytime when the survivor had gone to the fields to relieve herself. She alleged that one Vishal crept up behind her and grabbed her by the face. When she fell on the ground, she saw another man. They both then proceeded to rape her. When she managed to reach home after a while, she narrated the ordeal to her family and later went to file a police complaint. Start a conversation, not a fire. Post with kindness. Title: 'Why Is Dalit Assertion Called Jungle Raj and Upper Caste Rule Mangal Raj?'
body: Three men from Bihar discuss the state of local politics with The Wire as the election to the state assembly nears a close. Voters stand in long queues to cast their votes at a polling station during the second phase of Assembly elections at Diyara in Danapur, Tuesday, November 3, 2020. Photo: PTI As phase three of the Bihar assembly election draws near, opposition leader Tejashwi YadavтАЩs public image, allegations of misrule or тАШjungle rajтАЩ under his father Lalu Yadav, the question of caste assertion and minority issues take centre-stage for the final time. Senior editor Arfa Khanum Sherwani discussed all this and more in a conversation with senior journalist Satish K. Singh, professors Ratan Lal from the University of Delhi and Rizwan Kaiser from Jamia Millia Islamia University. The full transcript of their chat is given below. It has been prepared and translated from the Hindi original by Zobia Salam. ┬з Arfa Khanum Sherwani: Hello! Welcome to The Wire, I am Arfa Khanum Sherwani. Phase one of the Bihar elections has ended, two phases remain. The conjecture, however, that has remained constant is over Tejashwi YadavтАЩs rallies drawing massive crowds. Is this an indication of not just a change in power dynamics but social change too? At the same time, however, there is a constant talk of тАШJungle Raj (era of misrule)тАЩ, with the prime minister himself dubbing Tejashwi Yadav as the тАШprince of Jungle Raj (prince of the era of misrule)тАЩ тАУ тАШJungle Raj ka YuvraajтАЩ. While he [Tejashwi Yadav] responded in a very dignified manner, a lot of people continue to ask if Tejashwi Yadav will be completely different from Lalu Yadav? Some people go so far to say that they accept Tejashwi Yadav if he comes [to power] тАШminus Lalu YadavтАЩ, sans Lalu Yadav. If he leaves his father home; that they might vote for him if steps away from under his [Lalu YadavтАЩs] influence. There is a curiosity about тАШJungle RajтАЩ. What was it really? Why was it called so? Is it solely a term in savarna discussions, that as long as upper-castes hold power it is тАШMangal RajтАЩ or тАШera of good ruleтАЩ or тАШRam Rajya (rule of Lord Rama)тАЩ while lower-caste politics is labelled тАШJungle RajтАЩ? In todayтАЩs programme, we will try to understand all this since it will tell us about the kind of government it will be if Tejashwi Yadav were to form a government. What kind of a chief minister will he be? Will he be Lalu YadavтАЩs son or has he made his own brand? Is it even possible for him to leave Lalu YadavтАЩs legacy behind? Is it even sensible to do so, given Lalu YadavтАЩs term and his struggle is the foundation upon which Tejashwi Yadav dreams of becoming BiharтАЩs chief minister? LetтАЩs talk about this. To talk about this important issue, I have three special guests тАУ a kind of a dream panel for this topic тАУ Satish K Singh, senior journalist, who has been part of the history of TV news. He has built and developed several channels тАУ from Zee News to NDTV India. My second guest is Dr Ratan Lal, a professor at the University of Delhi, who is considered an authority on the topic of Dalit politics. Professor Rizwan Kaiser is also present. He is a professor of History at Jamia Millia Islamia and a well-known face on TV, who has looked at history from a different perspective. If one is ever stuck, one often read Rizwan KaiserтАЩs work, his opinions on issues.  A warm welcome to all three guests. The key point in this discussion is their [guests] background! Which is from Bihar. So, today, I have three authentic Biharis present with us. AKS: First of all, Professor Ratan Lal, I would like to know from you. What is this constant тАШintrigueтАЩ? Just what was this тАШJungle RajтАЩ that it is being used to scare people even today? What even is this тАШJungle RajтАЩ? Ratan Lal: If a woman is living her life on her own will, they consider it тАШJungle RajтАЩ! The entire concept behind it has to be understood. The whole idea comes from the Puranas. DonтАЩt they say тАШkalyug has arrivedтАЩ? What is kalyug after all? There should be a debate on it. Kalyug refers to the destruction of varnashrama dharma тАУ caste-based religious order. Kalyug implies a destruction, a backlash against caste system. When the caste system gets destroyed, questions are raised. It is either called kalyug or тАШJungle RajтАЩ/тАШera of misruleтАЩ. Also read: Nitish Kumar Once Had the Power to Unite BiharтАЩs Women Voters тАУ But No Longer What is disappointing is that the various secular alliances and the Mahagathbandhan or Grand Alliance that have been formed have never included [stands on] secularism, social justice or even privatisation in their agenda. To the ones who are calling it [Lalu YadavтАЩs term] тАШJungle RajтАЩ and to the spokespersons of the Mahagathbandhan/Grand Alliance, I ask: why arenтАЩt you defending it? Before the 90s, was it тАШMangal RajтАЩ in Bihar? Was it as pure as the Ganga, with people worshipping in it? Were Dalits, Brahmans, women living equally? Or were shots being fired inside colleges? People were entering hostels and firing shots. Colleges were divided as per caste; I have studied there myself! In Muzaffarpur, in MotahariтАжwe have seen it! No one dared to speak. So, this [is a] dominant narrative. Dominant section prepares a narrative. The sad part is that RJD spokespersons and the people of the Grand Alliance are so intellectually bankrupt that theyтАЩre unable to defend even Lalu YadavтАЩs rule! What can one say then? Fine, there may be a law and order problem, but is it any less in Uttar Pradesh? Narendra Modi тАУ in Gujarat, during the [2002 Godhra riots/Naroda Patiya] massacre about whom the [then] Prime Minister [Atal Bihari Vajpayee] had said that тАШ[he has] not followed raj dharmaтАЩ тАУ is now in Bihar calling it [Lalu YadavтАЩs term] Jungle Raj. Why is there no question in Gujarat, which saw a massacre? For the past five years we have been out on the streets, resisting. You are killing Muslims [and] Dalits, at times in the name of beef, at times on something else. Go and see in Uttar Pradesh just how many are getting killed. What kind of a raj/rule should this be called? AKS: But Dr Ratan Lal, if this was such a good era then why doesnтАЩt Tejashwi Yadav put up posters and pictures of Lalu Yadav? When asked about тАШJungle RajтАЩ, why does he say it [his term] wonтАЩt be like that? RL: This has to be answered by Tejashwi Yadav or their [RJDтАЩs] spokespersons. If I have to writeтАжI have read the history of post-Independence Bihar. I have even written an essayтАж I have witnessed caste oppression. Satish [K. Singh] sir and Rizwan [Kaiser] sahib may stop me if IтАЩm wrong when I say that in the past, they [upper castes/dominant castes] could herd an entire Dalit village just with one stick! A lone boy could shout тАШget out!тАЩ and entire villages of Dalits could be chased away! Guns are being fired. You need to look at the process of social change. The revolution is not born in a day. I have seen Bihar, North India closely тАУ as a teacher, as a reformer [and] as a journalist too! I have seen this, travelling from one village to the other. I too have worked in journalism; written an essay, an essay on diversity. Just with one stick, they used to chase away entire villages of Dalits. What type of rule was that? Narendra Modi and Yogi [Adityanath] should answer. AKS: Satishji, would Dalit assertion be called тАШJungle RajтАЩ? And is savarna suzerainty over society, politics, wealth, [and] power тАШMangal RajтАЩ? Satish K. Singh: Just because something is right doesnтАЩt make another thing wrong. I would say that the notion of a тАШJungle RajтАЩтАжif the Dalit assertion or the backward caste assertion that emerged, turns into kidnappings [and] extortionтАжand in that if 5-10 peopleтАжif a particular caste gains [dominance]тАжperhaps that has been termed тАШJungle RajтАЩ by the political opportunists. But you cannot deny that the backwards, OBCs and DalitsтАжif you talk about them in the mainstream тАУ and while I agree with what Dr. Ratan Lal is saying, that they could chase away entire villages by brandishing just one stickтАжbut if that is converted into a rule of goons, it is more treacherous! Girls were kidnapped in broad daylight. Schools and colleges were in such a bad condition. I belong to that area; I can testify personally. You may call this тАШassertionтАЩ, but what does a person like me have to do with all this! Even I could not leave my village after 6-7 pm. What kind of an assertion is this? The only aspect of тАШassertionтАЩ is that a process existed to everything. Would anyone say that MNREGA is wrong, even though itтАЩs a relief measure, welfare, a compulsion even? No one would say that the Right to Food shouldnтАЩt have been granted. This too had a process. It is a matter of process that you have been given a toilet, a roof over your head, a house тАУ this too is part of a larger processтАж Also read: Bihar Elections Phase 2: Does Tejashwi Yadav Have the Edge? тАжOn the argument that тАШJungle RajтАЩ existed even before the 90s, I agree with Dr Ratan Lal. Very much so! But if that is corrupted, it is more treacherous. You tell me this: In 15 years, if 70 thousand jobs were to being givenтАжduring liberalisation, when governments were downsizing everywhere, how will there be any assertion? If you wonтАЩt give jobs, how will there be any [assertion]? In the 15 years that political opponents term тАШJungle RajтАЩ, 70 thousand jobs were given. I say, at least 70 lakh shouldтАЩve been given. AKS: Rizwan Kaiser sahib, you just heard the experiences of the two panellists. True, the worlds that we come from, the lives we have lived shapes our views. But it seems as if тАУ if you look at the map of Indian politicsтАжthe terrifying stories that are told about those 15 years тАУ I have read those too. I may not have lived through it but I think and understand тАУ having looked at backward-caste politics not just as a journalist; IтАЩve done a PhD on it too. Nonetheless, I cannot live the experience of a Dalit or backward-caste person living in Bihar. So, I would like to know from you. You, too, come from Bihar. You are situated outside that caste system. As a historian; as a person who belongs to Bihar but has nothing to do with the caste system, how do you see it? Would you term it тАШJungle RajтАЩ or not? Rizwan Kaiser: I think what Ratan Lal ji and Satish Singh ji said was from their individual perspectives. But [on] this notion of тАШJungle RajтАЩ тАУ for those of us who want to analyse all these issues тАУ as a student of history, I would say that we have to record everything: good, bad, best [and] worst. Arfa I would like to tell you тАУ Ratan Lal ji is younger than me, Satish ji might be the same age so he might recall тАУ Karpoori Thakur jiтАЩs arrival in 1977. And the process of reservation that Karpoori Thakur started anew, wherein the weakest section within the OBC would be given more benefits. There used to be a savarna slogan in those times, which I would like to remind everyone of тАУ тАШ100 years ago, a Yadav was a cowherd; he still is and will remain soтАЩ. When Yadavs started seeking a position of respect he was called a cowherd. The politics of respect of the times of Lalu YadavтАж(obviously Dalits and backwards were considered outside the bounds of respect)тАжto some extent тАУ what Satishji was alluding to тАУ when they got power, the did misuse it. This too is a part of history and has to be taken a note of. But the fact also remains that they [dominant castes] could chase Dalits away by brandishing just one stick. And the OBC communities, Arfa, couldnтАЩt open their mouth in front of the bureaucrats. Thus, the slogan that Laluji gave тАУ of a politics of respect тАУ it was intended for the Dalits and OBCsтАж There was yet another factor that the other two panellists havenтАЩt yet mentioned тАУ they might elaborate upon it later тАУ you ask the Muslims what the 15-year long Lalu Prasad Yadav regime was like. During the 2005 elections, a journalist asked a paan seller who he will vote for. The paan seller replied, тАШObviously Laluji!тАЩ. So, the journalist as him a counter-question, тАШWhy Laluji?тАЩ. He replied тАШIf I vote for Laluji at least my paan stall will not be destroyedтАЩ. In other words, even a paan stall was secure because of LaluтАЩs rule. So just what is being called тАШJungle RajтАЩ? The bureaucracy of that very тАШJungle RajтАЩ shuddered in fear because of Lalu Yadav. Agreed, there shouldnтАЩt be riots. [But] for the 17% population of Bihar тАУ you can ask them тАУ was it тАШJungle RajтАЩ? Another consideration; for the sake of comparison тАУ and I would urge Ratan Lal and Satish Singh to contemplate upon this тАУ I belong to that generation of Biharis, Arfa, which began arriving in Delhi in the 80s. Lalu ji was nowhere to be seen; BiharтАЩs educational institutions had just begun their decline. The very presence of Bihari students in the University of Delhi, as well as Jawaharlal Nehru University, can be understood to mean that the educational situation in Bihar had undergone a collapse. Lalu Prasad Yadav was not to be seen anywhere. So, just which тАШJungle RajтАЩ is being talked about? Indeed, there was a culture of extortionтАж Also read: Watch | Why This Village in Bihar Has Pledged to Not Vote for Nitish Kumar AKS: I would like to move on to Professor Ratan LalтАжsince there are a lot of questionsтАж I understand all of your experiences and I want to document them through this programme. Since this is what, I feel, is important. This is not like any other discussion that I hold every day. I feel that the three of you have understood Bihar from your specific perspectives. We are documenting your life experiences via this programme. What I want to understand is that does pro-backward politics have to necessarily be anti-upper caste? Because we understand pro-backward politics as a form of progressive politics; a kind of politics that takes us towards progress. When we take note of upper-caste oppression, need we claim that if the backward-castes come to power, they too will be oppressive? How should we view these two eras of rule? How will we claim that the rule of the backward-castes is better than the rule of the upper-castes? RL: IтАЩm not defending any kind of crime or extortion. WhatтАЩs wrong is wrong and those wrongs have been committed during all regimes. The problem is when you only see half the history. Tell me one thing, before the 90s тАУ Congress was in a position of responsibility. People may not want to talk about the RJD of the time before the 90s, because of the alliance тАУ so, before the 90s, where did the party in power derive its social strength from? From the same source that strengthens BJP today! Or those that are with Nitish Kumar today. The society will remain the same, wonтАЩt it. If DalitsтАЩ, backwardsтАЩ, AdivasisтАЩ rights have been taken away; who has done this? A Bangladeshi immigrant? An American citizen? Who has committed deprived them of their rights? If in University of Delhi тАУ its been almost 100 years since [its inception] in 1922 тАУ there hasnтАЩt been one Dalit Vice Chancellor, is it an American who will be made [Vice Chancellor]? To raise such questions is our duty. I am not speaking as any party spokesperson, but as a student of history. In the 90sтАжI can tell you the names of the gangs in Bihar, in Muzaffarpur. They used to beat up rickshaw pullers; never pay them for their services. I am talking about Muzaffarpur! My house is situated thereтАжwhere the DM [G] Krishnaiyyah was killed. People used to come, eat at hotels without paying; used to get their shoes polished and not pay; used to travel by rickshaws, beat up the rickshaw driverтАжwhy donтАЩt they talk about all this? What тАШrajтАЩ was that, please define it. Who are the people making up this dominant narrative? Upper caste, upper-class people are defining this dominant narrative, which is why they donтАЩt want to talk about the history before the 90s. I want to talk from the time of Krishna [Sinha] babu onwards. I want to talk about the times before Independence. When elections happened in Bihar in 1937, what went on then? LetтАЩs debate that! What happened in the University of Patna, lets debate that! All universities were strongholds of upper-castes and were filled with goons. I can name them! Everyone knows that every hostel a .56 [revolver]. All IтАЩm saying is that IтАЩm not defending if someone orchestrated a kidnapping LalujiтАЩs regime. But if you want to criticise conscientiously then you must criticise the periods before and after it. AKS: Satishji, let us now focus on the current election. One narrative is that тАШwe accept Tejashwi [Yadav], we may even vote for him but so long as he comes without Lalu YadavтАЩ. What do you make of this? SKS: If a person with 4 kattha [land] defeats another with, say, 10 or 20 kattha [land], he wonтАЩt become rich. The one with 4 kattha [land] is poor, so also is the one who has 10 or 20 kattha [land]. Today, all of Bihar is battling for their bread and butter. This is not about caste. It is not about caste; I can show you forward castes that are battling extreme poverty. There is a massive crisis of employment today. It is a fight for bread and butter. It is a fight for existence. It was said that reservation will get people government jobs. But if only appointments are made will government jobs be given! No appointments are made! There is vacancy in only the army. If the state has exited from the production process and the slogan of тАШminimum government, maximum governanceтАЩ is raised, how will there be any jobs? Will they generate jobs in this era of COVID-19? Tejashwi [Yadav] тАУ heтАЩs a 31-year-oldтАжsorry to use this terminologyтАжa 31-year-old boy; heтАЩs not Lalu and yet attracting greater crowds than Lalu! Also read: тАШCurrent Govt Lacks DeterminationтАЩ: Tejashwi YadavтАЩs Rally in Siwan Stirs up Excitement AKS: But people are saying that they donтАЩt want LaluтАжтАЩwithout LaluтАЩ. IтАЩm talking about this equation. What do make of this? SKS: All IтАЩm saying is that the large crowd of attendees may or may not give [Tejashwi/RJD] votes but TejashwiтАЩs [Yadav] biggest contribution has been of bringing BiharтАЩs central issues тАУ of bread and butter, employment, business тАУ to fore. He made them key issues! He may not become Chief Minister. But the rally of a 31-year-old boy! You look at the numbers of attendees in NitishтАЩs and LaluтАЩs rallies and compare it with the crowds this time. This crowd has come for this [issue of employment]. It is a crowd for [specific] situation. It is true that the poor [and] the oppressed have it worse; truly! Where will you find money to spend for the three Ms тАУ everyone wants a mobile, smartphone that is; a motorbike and medicine? Expenditure is rising! Basic expenditure. The fundamental struggle is for bread and butter; for earnings. RL: I would like to add something. First of all, poverty has no relation to birth. Caste has a relation to birth. Secondly, you can keep Lalu away all you want but there can be no politics in Bihar without Lalu Yadav. Even the BJP asks for votes using Lalu YadavтАЩs name! AKS: тАжyes, against Lalu Yadav! RL: So, if RJD feels that it can fight elections without Lalu Yadav and upper-castes will consider them legitimate leaders, then they are deluded; they shouldnтАЩt be. An upper-caste will consider Tejashwi [Yadav] his leader only when he becomes CM and when the upper-caste holds the 80% creamy layer to his benefit. Only then he will truly consider Tejashwi [Yadav] his leader. AKS: Rizwan Kaiser sahib, does this politics of Tejashwi Yadav тАУ since it is what will decide if Tejashwi Yadav will come without Lalu Yadav or with Lalu Yadav or will Lalu Yadav be in hiding тАУ from your assessment of Tejashwi YadavтАЩs politics, is he trying to say, тАШyes IтАЩm backward caste, my politics is backward-caste politics but I am not against the forward-castesтАЩтАж тАШeven though I am not in a direct face-off with Narendra Modi, I will hide the Muslims behind the stageтАЩ? A kind of a hesitance тАУ I wonтАЩt call it hatred тАУ towards the skullcap and the beard can be seen in him [Tejashwi Yadav]. About the politics of aspiration that he wants to do тАУ which he has termed тАШeconomic justiceтАЩ тАУ do you feel that it will continue even after he becomes CM, if he wants to stay in politics in the longer run? Is it a short-term concern, that the election should be won first and all considerations should be left for later? RK: I would like to narrate an anecdote; it may not be the most appropriate but worth considering all the same. In our childhood, we used to read the story of a wolf who once asked a lamb why he was soiling the [river] water. The lamb replies, тАШSir, IтАЩm sitting in the direction opposite to the [river] stream, how can I soil the water?тАЩ The wolf then says, тАШIf not you, your father must have soiled it!тАЩ If you look at Lalu Prasad Yadav, in a way, he was a force at some stage but I donтАЩt think he is as big of a force today. You are focusing on Tejashwi [Yadav], but what about the forces behind Tejashwi [Yadav]? All of [CPI]ML is behind him, CPI, CPM, other various kinds of people тАУ what is called the тАШaspirational segmentтАЩ. And I agree with Satishji when he says that at the fundamental level it is a struggle for existence and survival. Tejashwi [Yadav] is the face; the forces behind Tejashwi [Yadav] are completely different people. Also read: Bihar: Independent Candidate Sanjay Sahni Accuses RJD Leader of Intimidation AKS: I want to add a question here since the discussion is not at all about whether Tejashwi [Yadav] is losing or winning. WeтАЩre trying to understand these elections by placing the political narrative and history on a map. So, my question is that even if Tejashwi Yadav winsтАжif there is a narrative of social justiceтАжlet me take the example of Narendra Modi тАУ heтАЩs not upper caste, he is an OBC but despite that if he is able to maintain upper caste supremacy then how does it matter who [the leader] is? If he is the bearer [of power] тАж our president is Dalit, but despite the huge incident happened at Hathras, he didnтАЩt utter a word to express his sorrow; not in the capacity of a Dalit but in the capacity of the President. So, what IтАЩm trying to say is that if a rule has to be established; if a rule has to be established of the politically dominant, then how does it matter whether Tejashwi [Yadav] wins or Nitish Kumar wins? RK: One thing must be kept in mind: currently the Bihar elections arenтАЩt even being fought on the issues of social justice. The Bihar election is being fundamentally fought on the issue of economic reconstruction. Reconstruction and reorganisation of Bihar. There is no call for social justice. He [Tejashwi Yadav] admits that socially we have Dalits, OBCs, other sections but weтАЩre with the forward castes and the minorities. In Bihar and in the entire country, Narendra Modi has marginalised Muslims to such an extent that other parties donтАЩt mention them out of the fear that they will, in some way, become a focus in their election campaigns. Tejashwi [Yadav] at least is courageous enough to say that we are taking all sections together, even the minorities. So, this election is not in the name of social justice, Arfa. It is for the reconstruction of the whole of Bihar in the realms of economy, employmentтАж AKS: Ratan Lalji, are these the demands of our times that there are no takers for a politics of social justice? Should a new kind of politics be done? RL: A politics of social justice exists and will continue to exist whether or not political parties want. We the activists will make it so! Secondly, economic justice has a relation to state policy. Is there any agenda on privatisation? Has any party said we will stop privatisation? That we will give representation to the small sector? If everyone has to serve [Gautam] Adani-[Mukesh]Ambani then what will you do? We know how one gets jobs in the media; how one gets private sector jobs, we know it all. Your bio-data speaks of your caste, religionтАжtry searching for homes in Delhi as a Muslim. No one will give you a house. See it [economic justice] is related to [state] policy. If you donтАЩt have a stand on privatisation, then you should drop it! Economic justice for whom? Reservation is related to suffering. For economic justice multiple state policies existтАж RK: IтАЩd like to say something Arfa. I feel that in the current scenario тАУ the entire conversation about social justice and various other things тАУ these things will always be talked about. It is inherent in this kind of politics. What IтАЩm saying is thatтАжif you remember the slogan given during the Mandal Commission implementation; the widespread OBC assertionтАжin Bihar there was a slogan that said тАШbhura baal saaf karoтАЩ тАУ remove the brown-haired [i.e. the forward-castes]. BiharтАЩs OBC assertion has surpassed this today. Now it does not talk about тАШremoving the brown-hairedтАЩ but says that our politics will be elevated to the state-level and everyone will find a place in it! Everyone will find a place in it only when BiharтАЩs own position is secureтАж RL: Even during LaluтАЩs era there was place for everyone тАУ you can check the data тАУ how many secretaries were what [caste], how many vice chancellors were what [caste], how many builders were what [caste]. Places were fixed even in the times of Lalu Yadav. The only difference being that Yadavs were the dominant caste. This was the only difference; the rest of the structure was the sameтАжit wasnтАЩt as if Lalu Yadav chased everyone [dominant castes] away from Bihar. Also read: Watch | Bihar Elections: Who Are Muslim Voters Going to Vote For? RK: In a way, yesтАж AKS: Satish ji for last comments I want to come to you. Is this 30-year-long chapter тАУ 15 years of Lalu Yadav, 15 of Nitish Kumar тАУ now ending? Is this now a new beginning? Do you think so? SKS: I want to present some facts in front of you Arfaji. You may even know this тАУ everyone would. In a state where no one knows what exists in the name of industry; no one knows how to get a job, whether or not one does get a job; which has high levels of malnutrition, which has the highest level of migration (out of all large states); where external forces contribute to 33% of its economy; where poverty ranges lies anywhere between 33% to 35 % and which has the maximum unemployed graduates (out of all large states) and which has the highest dropout rate. Then that state тАУ despite reservations, greater [reservation] for those who are more backward тАУ needs major relief! Only if all these things exist will people get them! You saw what happened in Russia, when the poor got a voice. Please run the state as per due process. Start businesses. Generate employment. And what is all this talk about creating a тАШnewтАЩ Bihar? The forward castes will dominate. Technology jobsтАжobviously the one who is educated will get it. The fundamental thing, in one phrase, is that it is a fight for bread and butter. The old times of those who studied using a chalk and slate have long gone. There is no online education in Bihar. You are preparing a new generation; you should at least provide employment. If you wonтАЩt give jobsтАж AKS: Yes, thank you very much. YouтАЩre saying that it is a fight for bread and butter; for who will be able to learnтАж RL: No, not just bread and butter. Bread and butter and respect. IтАЩm sitting here in the campus of the University of Delhi, despite having written a dozen books and research articles, [apparently] I lack meritтАжa SC judge says it too. The issue is not of employment but of respect.

Title: 2 Dalit sisters killed, bodies dumped in pond in UP's Fatehpur
body: 2 Dalit sisters killed, bodies dumped in pond in UP's Fatehpur Two Dalit sisters, both minors, were allegedly killed and their bodies dumped in a pond in a village in the Asodhar area of this Uttar Pradesh district, police said on Monday. The bodies of the victims with injury marks in the eyes were retrieved from the pond late in the evening, they said. ASP Rajesh Kumar said the bodies of Sumi (12) and Kiran (8), daughters of Dilip Dhobhi, a Dalit, were retrieved from the pond. Both the bodies had injury marks in the eyes, he said. The girls had gone to the field in the afternoon to get vegetables but did not return, the police said. The family members of the victims have alleged that the assailants killed the girls after an unsuccessful attempt to rape them, the officer said. The bodies were sent for a post-mortem examination and the report is awaited, the police said. Title: In BJP-RSS vision of India, Adivasis and Dalits should not have access to education: Rahul Gandhi
body: In BJP-RSS vision of India, Adivasis and Dalits should not have access to education: Rahul Gandhi Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Sunday attacked the government over a media report which claimed that scholarship for 60 lakh SC school students was stuck after central funding was ended and alleged that in the "BJP-RSS vision of India, Adivasis and Dalits should not have access to education". Along with his tweet attacking the government, Gandhi tagged the media report which said a key central scholarship scheme to help over 60 lakh Scheduled Caste students of classes 11 and 12 to complete their schooling has nearly shut down across more than 14 states after the Centre ended funding to states under a 2017 formula. "In BJP/RSS vision of India, Adivasis and Dalits should not have access to education," Gandhi alleged. "Stopping scholarships for SC-ST students is their way of ends justifying their means," the former Congress chief said in the tweet. Title: In India, Dalit women raped "to assert caste supremacy": Report
body: Lower-caste Dalit women in northern India are targeted for rape by upper caste men who usually escape justice as survivors bow to pressure to drop their cases, researchers found on Wednesday, reported Reuters. Only 10 per cent of forty rape cases involving Dalit women and girls in Haryana state ended with the conviction of all those charged, and these involved murder or victims under the age of six, found two rights groups, Equality Now and the Swabhiman Society. In almost 60 per cent of cases, the survivor withdrew her case and accepted a тАЬcompromiseтАЭ settlement outside the legal system, usually after unofficial village councils, or Khap Panchayats, coerced the women to abandon their quest for justice, it said. тАЬSurvivors are threatened, face violence, their families are ostracised and there is extreme pressure to stay silent,тАЭ Manisha Mashaal, founder of the Dalit rights group, Swabhiman Society, told the Thomson Reuters Foundation. тАЬTo access justice, survivors have to put their lives at risk and endanger their families as well.тАЭ HaryanaтАЩs director general of police Manoj Yadava said that he was unaware of the report, adding that they had a тАЬzero toleranceтАЭ policy to crimes against women in the state. The rights groups said men from dominant castes frequently use sexual violence as a weapon to reinforce caste and gender hierarchies, which place IndiaтАЩs 200 million Dalits on the lowest rung of an ancient caste hierarchy. The report highlights the challenges Dalits face in getting justice, despite tougher anti-rape laws introduced after a fatal gang rape in 2012, and nationwide protests last month over the alleged gang rape of a Dalit teen who later died. тАЬDalit womenтАЩs bodies are being used to assert caste supremacy and keep women тАШin their placeтАЩ,тАЭ Jacqui Hunt, Eurasia Director of womenтАЩs rights group, Equality Now, said in a statement. тАЬPerpetrators from dominant castes know they are likely to go unpunished because every branch and echelon of the system is weighted in their favour, and this impunity for rape creates an enabling environment that fosters further abuse.тАЭ In almost 90 per cent of cases, at least one of the accused was from a dominant caste, with men often acting in groups to carry out gang-rape and murder, the research found. The police frequently failed to record or investigate crimes when initially reported and were sometimes abusive or put pressure on survivors to drop cases, the report said, with survivors not given adequate advice about their legal rights. тАЬI can guarantee that every complaint that is brought to the police is being registered and investigated,тАЭ Yadava said. тАЬWe have 32 all-women police stations and a womenтАЩs helpline number. We are not hiding any cases coming to us or brushing them under the carpet. We are proud of our record of action against these crimes.тАЭ He added that out of court settlements were a social problem and awareness was being created to address it. But one 28-year-old survivor said her family were being harassed by a man who raped her in 2018 after she rejected his advances. тАЬEven before I could recover from the trauma of what had happened, his family and other upper-caste men were at our doorstep,тАЭ said the woman. тАЬI was forced to marry my rapist and then tortured by the family. I ran away and decided to fight my case. But every day they show up to threaten us and my mother cries in fear. I hope I get justice and all this trauma will finally end.тАЭ Copyright ┬й TKW Media Private Limited.

Title: Amit Shah Brought Food Hotel Ate Dalit House Claimed Mamata Banerjee
body: ржПржХрзБрж╢рзЗ ржнрзЛржЯрзЗрж░ ржЖржЧрзЗ рж░рж╛ржЬрзНржпрзЗ ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐рж░ ржмрж╛ржбрж╝ржмрж╛ржбрж╝ржирзНржд ржарзЗржХрж╛рждрзЗ; рж╕рзЛржоржмрж╛рж░ ржмрж╛ржБржХрзБржбрж╝рж╛рж░ ржЦрж╛рждржбрж╝рж╛рж░ рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ рж╕ржнрж╛ ржерзЗржХрзЗ; ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐ ржирзЗрждрзГрждрзНржм ржУ рж╕рзНржмрж░рж╛рж╖рзНржЯрзНрж░ржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣ржХрзЗ ржПржХрзЗрж░ ржкрж░ ржПржХ ржЖтАЩржХрзНрж░ржоржг ржХрж░рзЗржи ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржоржорждрж╛ ржмржирзНржжрзНржпрзЛржкрж╛ржзрзНржпрж╛рзЯред ржПржжрж┐ржи тАШржжрзБрзЯрж╛рж░рзЗ ржжрзБрзЯрж╛рж░рзЗ рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░тАЩ; ржкрзНрж░ржХрж▓рзНржкрзЗрж░ ржХрж╛ржЬ рж╢рзБрж░рзБ ржХрж░рж╛рж░ ржШрзЛрж╖ржгрж╛ ржХрж░рзЗржЫрзЗржи рждрж┐ржирж┐ред рж╕рзЗржЗ рж╕ржЩрзНржЧрзЗ ржжтАЩрж▓рж┐ржд ржмрж╛рзЬрж┐рждрзЗ ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣рзЗрж░ ржЦрж╛ржУрзЯрж╛ ржирж┐рзЯрзЗржУ ржХржЯрж╛ржХрзНрж╖ ржХрж░рзЗржи ржоржорждрж╛ ржмржирзНржжрзНржпрзЛржкрж╛ржзрзНржпрж╛рзЯред ржПржЫрж╛рзЬрж╛ ржПржХрж╛ржзрж┐ржХ ржЗрж╕рзНржпрзБрждрзЗ; ржПржжрж┐ржи ржХрзЗржирзНржжрзНрж░рзАрзЯ рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░ржХрзЗ ржЖтАЩржХрзНрж░ржоржг ржХрж░рзЗржи рждрж┐ржирж┐ рз╖ тАЬрж╣рзЛржЯрзЗрж▓ ржерзЗржХрзЗ ржЦрж╛ржмрж╛рж░ ржПржирзЗ; ржжтАЩрж▓рж┐ржд ржмрж╛рзЬрж┐рждрзЗ ржЦрзЗрзЯрзЗржЫрзЗржи ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣тАЭ; ржмрж┐тАЩрж╕рзНржлрзЛрж░ржХ ржжрж╛ржмрж┐ ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржоржорждрж╛рж░ред ржжрзБржжрж┐ржирзЗрж░ ржмрж╛ржВрж▓рж╛ рж╕ржлрж░рзЗ ржПрж╕рзЗ, ржмрж╛ржБржХрзБржбрж╝рж╛рзЯ ржжрж▓рзАрзЯ ржмрзИржаржХ рж╕рзЗрж░рзЗ; ржЖржжрж┐ржмрж╛рж╕рзА ржмрж┐ржнрзАрж╖ржг рж╣рж╛ржБрж╕ржжрж╛рж░ ржмрж╛ржбрж╝рж┐рждрзЗ ржжрзБржкрзБрж░рзЗрж░ ржЦрж╛ржмрж╛рж░ ржЦрзЗрзЯрзЗ ржЫрж┐рж▓рзЗржи; ржХрзЗржирзНржжрзНрж░рзАрзЯ рж╕рзНржмрж░рж╛рж╖рзНржЯрзНрж░ржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣ред ржПржжрж┐ржи ржмрж╛ржБржХрзБрзЬрж╛рж░ ржоржЮрзНржЪ ржерзЗржХрзЗ рж╕рзЗржЗ ржШржЯржирж╛ржХрзЗ ржирж┐тАЩрж╢рж╛ржирж╛ ржХрж░рзЗ, ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржмрж▓рзЗржи; тАЬрж╣рзЛржЯрзЗрж▓ ржерзЗржХрзЗ ржЦрж╛ржмрж╛рж░ ржПржирзЗ; ржжтАЩрж▓рж┐ржд ржмрж╛рзЬрж┐рждрзЗ ржЦрзЗрзЯрзЗ ржЧрзЗржЫрзЗржи ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣тАЭред рж╕рзЗржЗ рж╕ржЩрзНржЧрзЗ рждрж┐ржирж┐ ржмрж▓рзЗржи; тАЬрж░рж╛ржирзНржирж╛рж░ ржкрзНрж░рж╕рзНрждрзБрждрж┐рждрзЗ ржжрзЗржЦрж╛ ржЧрзЗржЫрзЗ ржзржирзЗржкрж╛рждрж╛ ржХрж╛ржЯрждрзЗ; ржЕржержЪ ржЕржорж┐ржд рж╢рж╛рж╣ ржЦрж╛ржЪрзНржЫрзЗржи ржЖрж▓рзБ-ржкрзЛрж╕рзНржд! ржЖтАЩржжрж┐ржмрж╛рж╕рзА ржнрж╛ржЗ ржмрзЛржирзЗрж░рж╛ ржПржЗ ржжрзНржмрж┐тАЩржЪрж╛рж░рж┐рждрж╛ ржзрж░рзЗ ржлрзЗрж▓рзЗржЫрзЗржитАЭред ржЖрж░ржУ ржкржбрж╝рзБржиржГ ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐ рждрзГржгржорзВрж▓рзЗрж░ тАШржмрж┐рж░рж╕рж╛ ржорзБржгрзНржбрж╛ ржмрж┐рждрж░рзНржХтАЩ, рж▓рж╛ржнрзЗрж░ рж▓рж╛ржн рж░рж╛ржЬрзНржп рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ ржХрж░рзНржорзАржжрзЗрж░ рж╢рзБржзрзБ ржЦрж╛ржмрж╛рж░ ржирж┐рзЯрзЗржЗ ржирж╛; ржЖтАЩржжрж┐ржмрж╛рж╕рзА рж╢рж┐ржХрж╛рж░рж┐рж░ ржорзВрж░рзНрждрж┐ ржорж╛рж▓рж╛ ржжрж┐рзЯрзЗ; рж╕рзЗржЗ ржорзВрж░рзНрждрж┐ржХрзЗ ржмрж┐рж░рж╕рж╛ ржорзБржирзНржбрж╛рж░ ржорзВрж░рзНрждрж┐ ржмрж▓рзЗ ржЪрж╛рж▓рж╛ржирзЛрж░ ржирж┐рзЯрзЗржУ; ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐ржХрзЗ ржЖтАЩржХрзНрж░ржоржг ржХрж░рзЗржи рждрж┐ржирж┐ред ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐ржХрзЗ ржХржЯрж╛ржХрзНрж╖ ржХрж░рзЗ ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржмрж▓рзЗржи; тАЬржжрж┐рж▓рзНрж▓рж┐рж░ ржорзЗрж╛ржжрзА рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░ ржПржоржи ржЖржЗржи рждрзИрж░рж┐ ржХрж░рзЗржЫрзЗ; ржпрж╛рждрзЗ рждрж╛рж░рж╛ ржЖрж▓рзБ ржирж┐рзЯрзЗ ржЪрж▓рзЗ ржпрж╛ржмрзЗред рж╕рж╛ржзрж╛рж░ржг ржорж╛ржирзБрж╖ ржЖрж▓рзБрж╕рж┐ржжрзНржз ржнрж╛рждржУ ржЦрзЗрждрзЗ ржкрж╛ржмрзЗржи ржирж╛тАЭред ржЖрж░ржУ ржкржбрж╝рзБржиржГ ржмржЮрзНржЪржирж╛рж░ ржЕржнрж┐ржпрзЛржЧ ржорж┐ржерзНржпрж╛, рж▓ржХржбрж╛ржЙржирзЗ ржЧрзНрж░рж╛ржорзАржг ржкрзНрж░ржХрж▓рзНржкрзЗ ржжрзЗрж╢рзЗрж░ ржоржзрзНржпрзЗ рж╕ржмржЪрзЗржпрж╝рзЗ ржмрзЗрж╢рж┐ ржЯрж╛ржХрж╛ ржкрзЗржпрж╝рзЗржЫрзЗ ржмрж╛ржВрж▓рж╛ ржПржжрж┐ржи ржмрж╛ржБржХрзБрзЬрж╛рж░ рж╕ржнрж╛ ржерзЗржХрзЗ ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржЬржиржЧржгржХрзЗ рж╕рждрж░рзНржХ ржХрж░рзЗ ржмрж▓рзЗржЫрзЗржи; ржмрж╛ржВрж▓рж╛рзЯ ржирж┐рж░рзНржмрж╛ржЪржирзЗрж░ ржЖржЧрзЗ рж╣рж┐ржВрж╕рж╛рж░ ржкрж░рж┐рж╕рзНржерж┐рждрж┐ рждрзИрж░рж┐ ржХрж░рж╛ рж╣ржмрзЗред ржПржжрж┐ржи рждрж┐ржирж┐ рж╕рждрж░рзНржХ ржХрж░рзЗ ржмрж▓рзЗржи; ржмрж┐ржЬрзЗржкрж┐ ржХрзНрж╖ржорждрж╛рзЯ ржЖрж╕рж▓рзЗржЗ ржПржиржЖрж░рж╕рж┐ ржкрзНрж░рзЯрзЗрж╛ржЧ ржХрж░ржмрзЗ ржкрж╢рзНржЪрж┐ржоржмржЩрзНржЧрзЗред ржнрзЛржЯрзЗрж░ ржЖржЧрзЗ; ржкрзНрж░рждрзНржпрзЗржХ ржорж╛ржирзБрж╖рзЗрж░ ржХрж╛ржЫрзЗ рж╕рж░ржХрж╛рж░рж┐ ржкрж░рж┐рж╖рзЗржмрж╛ ржкрзМржБржЫрзЗ ржжрзЗржУрзЯрж╛ рж╣ржмрзЗ ржмрж▓рзЗ; ржкрзНрж░рждрж┐рж╢рзНрж░рзБрждрж┐ ржжрзЗржи ржорзБржЦрзНржпржоржирзНрждрзНрж░рзА ржоржорждрж╛ ржмржирзНржжрзНржпрзЛржкрж╛ржзрзНржпрж╛рзЯред ржХрж▓ржХрж╛рждрж╛ рж░рж╛ржЬрзНржп ржжрзЗрж╢ ржЖржирзНрждрж░рзНржЬрж╛рждрж┐ржХ рж░рж╛ржЬржирзАрждрж┐ рж╕рзНржмрж╛рж╕рзНржерзНржп ржЦрзЗрж▓рж╛ ржЕрж░рзНржержирзАрждрж┐ рж╕ржорзНржкрж╛ржжржХрзАрзЯ ржХрзНрж░рж╛ржЗржо ржХрж░рзНржорж╕ржВрж╕рзНржерж╛ржи ржмрж┐ржЬрзНржЮрж╛ржиржкрзНрж░ржпрзБржХрзНрждрж┐ рж▓рж╛ржЗржлрж╕рзНржЯрж╛ржЗрж▓ ржнрзНрж░ржоржг рж░рж╛ржирзНржирж╛ржмрж╛ржирзНржирж╛ ржлрзНржпрж╛рж╢ржи ржмрж┐ржЙржЯрж┐ ржЯрж┐ржкрж╕ ржмрж┐ржирзЛржжржи рж╣рж▓рж┐ржЙржб ржмрж▓рж┐ржЙржб ржЯрж▓рж┐ржЙржб рж░рж╛рж╢рж┐ржлрж▓ ржзрз░рзНржо-рж╕ржВрж╕рзНржХрж╛рж░ ржЕржлржмрж┐ржЯ

Title: Caste, food and ideological imposition ├В┬╖ Dalit Camera
body: Eggs have been denied to children as part of the mid day meals in schools for several years. Described as the тАШmenstrual dischargeтАЩ of the hen, eggs are labelled as тАШsinfulтАЩ, тАШviolentтАЩ, and agitating the senses, with egg eaters deserving to be тАШdestroyedтАЩ. Written by Dr. Sylvia Karpagam|Bengaluru|November 22, 2020 Meghala (6 year old dalit girl) тАУтАЬMalnutrition or pneumonia or malnutrition?тАЭ Meghala, a tiny girl of 6 years, had large, luminous eyes that looked soulfully at you. She lived with her older sister Ruth aged 12 and visually impaired mother, Murugamma in a tin shed in Roshan Nagar in DJ Halli, Bengaluru and was hungry most of the time. Severely malnourished, weighing only 12 kg, she didnтАЩt come under the radar of either the Women and Child Development (WCD) department or the Health department. Following media and civil society outrage after her death, the Women and Child development minister claimed that her death was not due to malnutrition but due to pneumonia, while the Health department laid the blame squarely on her nutritional status, denying pneumonia as a causative factor. However, the fact of the matter was that this little dalit girl child had been betrayed by both the departments and that she had been sucked into a vicious cycle where malnutrition increased the risk of disease which in turn further aggravated the malnutrition. According to the National Family Health Survey 4, [NFHS4, 2015], less than 10% of the 6 to 23 month children in India are adequately fed. Now, with the Covid -19 pandemic and lockdown, supply of mid day meals/dry rations at government/aided schools and anganwadis has deteriorated even further. Geetha (Activist and mother)-тАЬItтАЩs better not to give children food than to give this kind of food which is neither nutritious nor tastyтАЭ Geetha is an activist and more importantly a mother. She knows that onions, garlic, other spices, eggs and other animal sources of food help improve both the taste and nutritional quality of the food. She also unequivocally asserts that this is certainly not being provided to the children by one of the largest contractors for the government mid day meal scheme тАУThe Akshaya Patra Foundation. This organisation, an initiative of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON) with a religious prerogative of тАШadvocating a lacto-vegetarian diet, strictly avoiding meat, fish and eggsтАЩ considers onions and garlic in food as тАЬlower modes of nature which inhibit spiritual advancementтАЩ. Geetha bemoans the casteist/religious/cultural indoctrination by Akshaya patra which vehemently refuses to use onion and garlic in their cooking inspite of this being mandated in State government menu. Coincidentally, research conducted by Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysuru, shows that the absorption of zinc and iron from cooked food is higher in the presence of onion and garlic. Iron and zinc, along with many other minerals and vitamins, as well as protein, are essential in the management of iron deficiency anemia, which, according to NFHS4 data has a prevalence of 53.9 percent in children belonging to the general category and 60.5, 63.1 and 58.6 in children belonging to SC, ST and OBC castes respectively. The National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education (MDM Scheme), launched in August 1995 lays emphasis on providing cooked meals with a minimum 450 тАУ 700 calories and 8-12 grams of proteins and was further converted by the National Food Security Act (NFSA) 2013 into a legal right upto Class 8. Over 94% of the children in government and government aided schools come from Scheduled Caste, Scheduled Tribe, Other Backward Classes and minority communities. Among children (under five years) belonging to Scheduled Tribes, 43.8 percent children under five are stunted (less than expected heights for age) and 45.3 are underweight (less than expected weights for age), while 42.8 percent children from the Scheduled Caste community are stunted and 39.1 percent are underweight. For a majority (94%) of children in government schools who are from marginalised communities and malnourished, garlic, onion and eggs form an important part of their diets, limited only by the factor of affordability. That these are being denied to them by communities that donтАЩt even attend government schools, is a good example of how caste-based discrimination of children from vulnerable communities is institutionalised. Eggs have been denied to children as part of the mid day meals in schools for several years. Described as the тАШmenstrual dischargeтАЩ of the hen, eggs are labelled as тАШsinfulтАЩ, тАШviolentтАЩ, and agitating the senses, with egg eaters deserving to be тАШdestroyedтАЩ. If, instead of this unscientific propaganda, the nutritional value of eggs had been the primary deciding factor, children would have been given eggs as part of the mid day meal scheme on 5 days of the week. Along with this, if beef bans and its associated criminalisation/mob murders of beef eaters had not existed, stunting, undernutrition, iron/zinc/B12 deficiency would have been addressed by the country quite efficiently. To retain the unscientific, casteist status quo, people are instead being subjected to drugs and poor dietary advice. Doors are also being thrown open to greedy corporates to bring in fortification, processed foods, ready to eat therapeutic pastes etc. As part of the process of encouraging school based hot cooked meals, an interim order of the Supreme court regarding mid day meals, dated 20th April 2004 mandates that тАЬIn appointment of cooks and helpers, preference shall be given to Dalits, Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.тАЭ In practice, this has faced severe backlash and centralised kitchens such as Akshaya patra, could as well be a way to reinforce age old practices that do not allow dalit women near food preparation areas. Saranamma (Dalit traditional birth attendant/sulagithi) тАУ тАЬCome IтАЩll walk with you to the other side of the river and weтАЩll come back with the light of your lifeтАЭ Saranamma is an 85-year-old traditional birth attendant/ dai/sulagithi in Karnataka. She is a dalit woman. Her role is literally to accompany a pregnant woman physically, psychologically and emotionally throughout her pregnancy and post partum period. She mostly has magic in her hands тАУ either when she is massaging away aches and pains, or when she is preparing a magic drink to reduce some mysterious pregnancy/post partum discomfort, or when she is putting together ingredients to create a nutrient packed meal to build up the stamina of the mother. She has learnt, from a long oral tradition handed down to her over the years from her mother or mother in law, exactly what can relieve problems arising during pregnancy, labour or later. Sometimes she adds fish as the secret ingredient, sometimes turmeric, sometimes mutton, sometimes something else. Saranamma can take one look at a woman and KNOW when her labour is due, whether it is real or false labour pain, if it will be complicated (needing referral) or smooth, or whether the woman just needs to use the toilet. She will pack a small bag with her essentials and walk long distances through difficult routes accompanying anyone who knocks at her door with the message тАШshe is in labourтАЩ. One fine day, the Government of India suddenly decided that all deliveries would need to take place in institutions and the practice of home delivery was made illegal, almost overnight. The sulagathi was relegated to the status of a criminal. [A brahmin тАШayurvedicтАЩ specialist was part of a group that wanted to document the practices of the sulagathi. She тАШanalysedтАЩ all the data related to food and treatment, eliminated all the animal source food related preparations and presented the data at a national conference as тАШthe rich Ayurvedic tradition of IndiaтАЩ] Khatija Bee (Muslim senior citizen living in an urban deprived area) тАЬThe doctor says donтАЩt eat meat, donтАЩt eat eggs. Eat only fruits and vegetables. Still my sugar levels havenтАЩt come below 350тАЭ Khatija Bee from Lingarajpuram, Bangalore had a blood sugar of 360 and blood pressure of 190/100 when last examined in August during a medical camp. She also complains of breathlessness and chest pain on exertion. She was referred to the only government cardiology hospital in the State, for тАЬemergency management and treatment of cardiac condition, only to be told that she could not be treated тАШbecause of CovidтАЩтАЭ. India has the dubious distinction of being the diabetes capital of the world, with 8.7% people in the age group of 20 тАУ 70, or 50 million people living with diabetes in India. It is an attributable risk factor for several complications affecting the eyes, heart, kidney, nervous system and circulatory system. People who have had a heart attack or stroke have a high likelihood of a previous history of diabetes and diabetic retinopathy contributes to 2.6% of global blindness. Patients in India with diabetes induced kidney failure face the grim prospect of dialysis, with its exorbitant cost and poor availability, or a kidney transplant, which is often mired in illegality. Anyone who is diagnosed with diabetes in India is likely to repeatedly hear one specific bit of unsolicited advice ad nauseum and that is to тАЬStop eating meatтАЩ. In reality, cutting down on sugars, reducing traditional cereals (read carbohydrates), and increasing the consumption of animal source foods, has the ability to drastically prevent or reduce the large scale prevalence of diabetes and its complications. In India, distancing oneself from the тАШpolluting, inferiorтАЩ meat and meat eaters is a deliberately exaggerated casteist behaviour marker. Although only about 30% of Indians self identify as vegetarian, this too could be an inflated number because of the stigma surrounding meat eating. Ironically, milk and milk products are conveniently labelled as тАШvegetarianтАЩ ignoring their animal based composition. In India, politics, culture, religion, caste and economics around cereals, vegetables, fruits, pulses, oils, eggs, meat etc., prevent any rational or evidence based conversations around food. Even a suspicion of transporting beef or a mention of its nutritional/cultural/religious value can trigger a series of events ranging from abuse, arrest, harassment and lynching. The idea that dalit, Adivasi and OBC children should be grateful for whatever food is тАШgivenтАЩ to them is deeply ingrained in the minds of doctors, activists, researchers, policy makers and pretty much the entire gamut of citizens in the country. The idea that children have inviolable rights to healthy, nutritious, tasty, clean, culturally relevant food is lost on most people who claim these same rights only for themselves. This is the crux of how caste discrimination operates in India, reinforcing all the hegemonic, hierarchical imbalances that are so evident that they become invisible. An entire mafia has formed around childrenтАЩs food, making it almost impossible for children to have one decent meal as legally mandated by the NFSA. Organisations like ISKCON or Akshaya patra, with blatantly casteist/religious ideology are placed on a pedestal above criticism and beyond usual accountability frameworks. It is of utmost importance that dalit, Muslim, Adivasi, Christian communities etc. that consume (and enjoy) eggs, beef, pork, fish, poultry etc. come together to reclaim their food sovereignty and challenge the hegemonic imposition of nutritionally inferior тАШsattvikтАЩ foods. Food could be a powerful rallying factor to bring oppressed communities together. Dr. Sylvia Karpagam is a public health doctor and researcher who works on the social determinants of health such as caste, gender and nutrition. captures narratives, public meetings, songs, talks, discussion on dalits. It is largely run by students and their expenses are mostly met by themselves. At present our people work in Hyderabad, Mumbai and Calcutta. Support with a Donation Via Scroll.in|29th July,2020| The writer said that the CentreтАЩs action was fuelled due to the тАШalternative narrative to Hindu fascismтАЩ that these people represent. Author Arundhati Roy on Wednesday criticised the governmentтАЩs тАЬrelentless and ongoing incarceration of activists, academics and lawyersтАЭ inтАж Read MoreContinue Written by Dr. Ajay Sekher| Kerela| Oct 8, 2020Via: Countercurrents.org We are going through one of the most dismal times in the history of post-independence India. Anyone who resists, anyone who speaks for the greater common good, for truth and justice, isтАж Read MoreContinue On 10th September 2019, Dr. Hany BabuтАЩs house was raided in Delhi by a team of 50 police personnel who claimed they are from Pune. In this video, Hany speaks about what transpired during the raid. It has also been transcribed in this article. Read MoreContinue Debt, due to marriage and medical expenses along with others are the most common reasons for which these Dalits are compelled to sell their land. Read MoreContinue In Shahdara, Seema has opened a small parlor in the Valmiki Basti. She says, тАЬI have seen the men of my neighbourhood die doing this. They have slowly vanished in the sewer one after the other. One goes and the other followsтАж. Read MoreContinue Organised political movements have not yet agreed to address and rewrite the Kerala Model Development plan or find solutions for the contemporary problems that Kerala faces. It is in this context that a new democratic movement is initiated to secure the rights to resources for the marginalised sections of Kerala. Read MoreContinue Extreme try hard propaganda trying to make themselves look тАЬwokeтАЭ. An organization serves free meal to children without asking their caste, creed, religion and gender to which the writers has a problem, namely : тАЬWhy wont u kill more animals?тАЭ. woke activist: тАЬItтАЩs better not to give children food than to give this kind of food which is neither nutritious nor tastyтАЭ Woke logic : Meat is the only thing that has nutrition. vegetables , food grains ,pulses are nutrition less. I wont feed anyone and I wont allow anyone else to feed others until and unless they kill thousands of innocent animals. Disgusting People. Two questions for you Aman Deep Is there a тАШright to foodтАЩ тАУ that I should be allowed to / able to eat what is food for me? If yes, then meat, fish, eggs are a part of food for many. Do you think this right can be taken away because тАЬAn organization serves free meal to children тАЭ тАУ Do you think food is a favour you are doing for these children? Would you be Ok if Government forced you to eat meat? If not, then why should you support the Government preventing people who eat meat, onion and garlic from doing so? The mid day meal program is a nation wide program is funded by government, meaning public money. In which case there cannot be any rationale in forcing the dietary habits of some people on others. Such force is a crime. So who is disgusting? Is it not those people who use force on other people and decide their diet for them? By advocating Veganism among non upper castes, what do the upper castes gain? IsnтАЩt meat consumption, one of the main reasons of climate change? IsnтАЩt type 2 diabetes caused by inactivity or stress? IsnтАЩt malnutrition caused by poverty? I mean there are a lot of inconsistencies in the article, in many instances I feel you are just reaching for things without sufficient facts to back your claimsтАж.. I agree with some of the comments above regarding inconsistencies. This article is extremely biased. IтАЩm in no way a supporter of ISKCON but its actually not a casteist organization..the opposite in fact! Many caste conscious Hindus shun it outright precisely because the organization embraces тАЭ mlechasтАЭ and other castes as long as they have love for Lord Krishna. Yes perhaps reflexive despising of non тАЬsattvikтАЭ food is not helpful in a public health crisis involving malnutrition but why blame organizations like Akshaya Patra? Why canтАЩt governmental food schemes work side by side to provide eggs or whatever is considered nutritionally appropriate? So if akshaya patra provides lunch why not breakfast by somebody else ? Here in the west children from non meat eating backgrounds often face the opposite problems where the dominant culture often doesnтАЩt respect their dietary food choices. So that should be the problem not a blanket blaming of caste or ayurveda in my opinion. Further, there is a clinate crisis and meat production is a big contributor to it. So surely that must be addressed as well. Another pseudo lecture. It is time people move away from meat, eggs, milk and other animal products. The cruelty of animal husbandry industry is well known. Animals, which should be leading a free life in the forests are forcefully domesticated and used as a source of meat and other products. Animals are also used for hard labour or other such activities. It is high time that people realise that machines can replace animals and human beings can live without meat or animal products. I do agree with you. ItтАЩs logical to follow the food habits of our ancestors. I am of the opinion that the Govt should not have a say in what we eat, whom we worship and whom we marry. Interestingly India is the largest exporter of beef since 2014. It appears that our Govt is ok with killing animals as long it fetches $. Ironically most of the beef exporters are Indian Hindus who conveniently name their company after Muslim pronouns. Please check out google for тАЬLargest exporters of beef in IndiaтАЭ I feel your pain, Animals going through. Plants do posses life and feelings as per the science, Shall we stop eating plants and plant based food as itтАЩs cruel to kill a plant which cannot even raise a voice unlike animals? Fruits and vegetables are produced by plants for themselves not for humans. Everyone has their right to chose their food. Akshaya PatraтАЩs discussion is not appropriate, they are doing their part to the needy. iskon is a relegious entity, itтАЩs not proper to discuss about them as they are a propaganda like madharsas or missionaries, However satwik food is inferior food at nutritional level given same weight of food. Take an example of 100 gms chicken and 100 gms chickepeas. Volume of 100 gms chicken is way lesser on cooking than Peanuts or chickepeas or any other vegetable for the same amount of calories and nutritional value. I do strongly agree with the above mentioned points about casteism but would like to recommend you to not glorify the practice of dai-conducted or non-institutional delivery since they have long been proven to increase maternal as well as infant mortality and you should be aware of it as you are a public health doctor. A sick nation indeed, sick in body and sick in mind. The brahmin, scourge of the country, curse for the depressed, shame of humanity, excuse for humans, will ensure the country falls into abyss and they survive to see it happen. Truly tragic. They have done it in the past and they will certainly try to do it again. I seriously donтАЩt get why people like you possess hate for brahmin like they have done something wrong. Indians were assaulted by Mughals, English, savotaged our rich culture, looted our treasures but still people says brahmin did so and so. Seriously how could someone so stupid !! According to you if brahmins are the scourge for this country..then тАЬMuslims are the biggest oneтАЭ. Seriously, what brahmins has to do with all this article..? Title: Was Always Thrown in Jails Ahead of Bihar Polls, Says Manoj Manzil, the Debutant Dalit CPI(ML) MLA
body: Manoj Manzil. (Image: Twitter) "Whenever elections are around the corner, they send me to jail,тАЭ the 36-year-old first time CPI(ML) MLA, Manoj Manzil, said. In an attempt to prevent him from campaigning, the CPI(ML) leader said that he was thrown behind bars in the last Vidhan Sabha elections in 2015 in Bihar. "But I managed to secure 35,000 votes even then,тАЭ he said. This time also, he was picked up soon after he filed his nomination from his native Agiaon (SC reserved) seat. Despite all odds, Manzil, the son of a landless farmer couple, secured 86,327 votes, 48,550 more than his nearest rival JD(U)'s Prabhunath Prasad. In 2018, Manzil received accolades for his initiative 'Sadak Pe School', when he, along with his associates from AISA (the students' wing of CPI(ML), gathered children of poor Dalit and Muslim families and started their own schools on public roads. 'Sadak pe School' became simultaneous sites of sit-in protests and places of alternative schooling. Manzil spoke to News18 as a first-time MLA on caste violence, his ascent into left politics and his plans for the future. Could you tell us a bit about your childhood? тАЬI was the only child of a poor landless labour couple. They still work on other peopleтАЩs farms. When the farm season ends, my father works in a brick kiln. Our small house is built on 3 dismil (0.01 hectare) of land. I went to Arrah for my graduation and use to teach children in order to support my education. But several times I had to drop out of studies because at times there was not enough to eat at home.тАЭ How did you get into left politics? My family had introduced me to left politics in a way. My father, while being a farm hand, was also a CPI(ML) cadre. My uncle, who was part of Jay Prakash movement, spent his life fighting feudalism and spent 14 years in jail. My mother was also, in her own way, part of the resistance. But the other, the bigger reason was our history. In the '70s, we had repeatedly seen and suffered at the hands of the feudal militia. There is a village not very far from here, and now it is part of my constituency, called Hadiyabad. That's where my mother is from. Private armies owned by feudal lords set it to fire in the early 70s. Not many people survived. My mother was one of them. But she had lost her everything in that carnage. Later on, we saw the aftermath of massacres that were committed by Ranvir Sena (private militia of Bihar's landlords accused of murdering hundreds of Dalits) and we would weep, all the time. As time passed, we suffered police atrocities also. I've got 30 FIRs slapped against me for my activism in education, land reforms etc., by the police and five times I've been to jail. Over time, all these things accumulated in my mind to the point where I decided to work not just for my family but for all the families in my area. How does it feel to finally be an MLA? I haven't found much time since the election results were announced. Two children in my constituency died from a cylinder blast. Just now I finally finished the formalities of getting Rs 8 lakh compensation to the family. Your partyтАЩs remarkable performance has started talks about the possible revival of the left. We worked on the ground for all sections. All our associates from other parties also put their hearts and souls into helping me. There is disappointment over the three seats that our party has lost by margins of less than 150 votes. But we take heart from what we have achieved. Finally, how did you come to have this name? [Laughs] Yes this wasn't my original name, it was Manoj Kumar. I was quite interested in literature. I used to write and direct plays. And one of the words that I kept coming across repeatedly, and which really moved me, was 'Manzil' [destination/goal]. So I took on that name.

Title: UP: 15-year-old Dalit girl set ablaze by jilted lover in Ballia
body: UP: 15-year-old Dalit girl set ablaze by jilted lover in Ballia In a shocking incident, a 15-year-old Dalit girl was set ablaze in a village in Ballia district by a youth for spurning his sexual advances. The police said that the accused, Krishna Gupta, 21, has been arrested. The victim was admitted to a hospital in Ballia but as her condition worsened, she was shifted to Varanasi for advanced treatment. The incident took place late on Friday night. Dubhar police station SHO Anil Chandra Tiwari said that on the complaint f the girl's father, the police have registered a case against the accused under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, the Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. The girl's father told the police that the accused abducted his daughter from house and set her on fire as she had been consistently rejecting the man's sexual advances towards her.
